editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: LOVE AND HONOVR, Written by W. DAVENANT Knight. Preſented by His Majeſties Servants at the Black-Fryers.
LONDON, Printed for Hum: Robinſon at the Three Pidgeons, and Hum: Moſeley at the Princes Armes in St. Pauls Church-yard. 1649.

list.item:
His brother
The Duke of Millaine
Diſguiſed like Embaſſadors.

Alteſto
Frivolo
Triſtan
Officers and Souldiers.

div.head: Act 1. Scaena 1.
div.stage: A Retreate being ſounded as from far, Enter Vaſco, Alteſto, Frivolo.

sp.speaker: Vaſco.
sp.l: HEark boyes? they ſound us a retreat? this skirmiſh (ſirs)
Was no rare paſtime to continue at;
'Tis ſaffer wraſtling in a bed; give me
Hence-forth your white fac'd foe, a plumpe faire enemie
That weares her head peece lac'd; I'm for a cambrick helmet, I.

sp.speaker: Alteſto.
sp.l: And yet theſe mighty men of Millain got
But little by the ſport; ſome of them ſhall
Vouchſafe to weare a ſingle arme heareafter,
Two wodden leggs too, and limpe their dayes out
In an Hoſpitall.

sp.speaker: Frivolo
sp.l: How? an Hoſpitall?

sp.speaker: Vaſco.
sp.l: A rode, a rode; your highway ſir is now
Your onely walke of ſtate for your maim'd ſoldier.
Your Hoſpitalls and penſions are reſeru'd
For your maim'd Mercer, decay'd ſonnes o'th ſhop,
That have been often crackd not in their crownes
Like us, but in their credit ſir.

sp.speaker: Frivolo.
sp.l: And placket ſquires, that have bin long diſeas'd
In their Lords ſervice; a ſcore of duckets
Shall bribe them into place, where they may ſleep,
And eate, and pray too, but with breath ſo much
Vnholſome, th'ayre can hardly purify't
And make it fit to reach neare heaven.

sp.speaker: Alteſto.
sp.l: Well, the ſurprize o'th cittadell, wherein
The Duke had plac'd his daughter, with the Ladies
Of her traine, and treaſure too, was a ſervice
Of moſt rare work.

sp.speaker: Vaſco.
sp.l: Juſt when they ſally'd out
To cut our Rere in peeces, then ſteale in
By Ambuſh wiſely layd, and make them all
Our prize, was miracle.

sp.speaker: Frivolo.
sp.l: They ſay his daughter ſcap'd, and fled, with her
As her beſt guard, one they call Leonell
Whom our Count Proſpero purſu'd.

sp.speaker: Vaſ. Triſtan?
sp.l: Welcome; is all our pillage waggond
Shall it to night ſee Turin?

sp.speaker: Triſtan.
sp.l: Alls ſafe my luſty leader; our horſe too
Have ſounded a retreat; and the foe ſneakes▪
He walkes with's hands in's pockets like a skipper
In a froſt.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Well, let me reckon my eſtate;
Firſt a widdow priſoner.

sp.speaker: Alteſto.
sp.l: Mine's a maide priſoner,
Young my Vaſco, ſhe's yet in her firſt bluſh,
And I've diſpatch'd her unto Turn too
My Mothers houſe, thy priſoner in her company,
They are acquainted.

sp.speaker: Vaſco.
sp.l: You have the luck; theſe bald chinnes are as familiar
With their good ſtarrs, as with ſpur-rowells,
Play with them, and turn'em which way they pleaſe;
I fought as well as he; and yet (forſooth)
His priſoner muſt be faire, and young, & mine
So old ſhe might have given Hercules ſuck,
Now ſhe ſucks too, for ſhe hath no teeth left,
In one moneth ſhe'l coſt me as much in cawdles
And ſweet candy, as her ranſome comes too.

sp.speaker: Fri
sp.l: But you have other pillage Captaine.

sp.speaker: Vaſ
sp.l: Let me ſee, 3 Barbarie horſes with rich
Capariſons, 2 Cheſts o'th Generalls cloths.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: And I 2 cheſts o'th Generalls plate.

sp.speaker: Friv.
sp.l: In thoſe I ſhare Alteſto.

sp.speaker: Uaſco
sp.l: How? plate? ſhall we incounter our ſowe'd fiſh
And broyld Pullen in ſilver ſervice rogues?
Like furr'd Magnificoes?

sp.speaker: Frivolo.
sp.p: We ſhall Captaine, but you may dip your morſell in good china earth.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: All your plate Uaſce, is the ſilver handle
Of your old priſoners franne.

div.stage: Enter Proſpero (wounded) and Evandra (her armes in a ſcarfe Piniond.)

sp.speaker: Triſt.
sp.l: Here comes Proſpero the valiant Count.

sp.speaker: Uaſ.
sp.l: And with him the brave prize.

sp.speaker: Praſ.
sp.l: Evandra do not mourne, I that have made
You captive thus with hazard of my youth
And blood, ſhall think you now as worthy of
My care, as of my volour in the fight;
Can I eſteeme you leſſe by being mine?

sp.speaker: Evand.
sp.l: What have I done (unknown unto my heart)
That I ſhould tempt your valour to ſo great
A 〈◊〉 as my captivity? or are my crimes
Obſerv'd more than my prayers, that heaven ſhall leave
Me to become the ſcorne of victorie?

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: It is the ſad preheminence of your
Exemplar birth, and beauty, to conferr
Honour on him that is your conqueror.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Honour? is that the word that hath ſo long
Betrayd the Emulous world, and foold the nobleſt race
Of men, into a vex'd and angry death?
If 'twere a vertue 'twould not ſtrive t'inthrall,
And thus diſtreſſe the innocent.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: I am the warrs diſciple, and ſince firſt
I had the growth to weare a ſword, I nere
Was taught how to ſubdue by reaſon but
By ſtrength. Alteſto?

sp.speaker: Alteſto.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Take here this Lady to your charge, conduct
Her unto Turin, and there guard her in
My houſe till my approach.

sp.speaker: Alteſto.
sp.l: I ſhall my Lord.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Let her be ſafe Alteſto in thy care
On forfeiture of life, ſhe is my priſoner
And th' nobleſt in the field, the beautious
Heire of Millaine; had not my niggard ſtars
Intended me but halfe a courteſie,
The Duke her Father had lamented now
Under the ſame fate.

sp.speaker: Vaſco.
sp.l: I could wiſh your Lordſhip would beleeve me,
A fitter man, to take charge of the Lady.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: VVhy Captaine?

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: You could not commit her to an Eunuch
VVith more ſafety; if the great Turke knew me
(Honeſt Achmet) he would truſt me in's Seraglio
(By this hand) without defalking one graine beneath the waſte.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Succeſſe hath made you wanton Cap.

sp.speaker: Uaſ.
sp.l: Beſides (my Lord) I have tane an old Abeſſe
Priſoner, O ſuch a Governeſſe for a
Young maid, ſheel read to her ſuch homilies,
And teach her ſuch receipts out of the Fathers,
How to cure the toothach, preſerve plumms,
And boyle Amber poſſits, will make her ſir
In three dayes a very St.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: VVell you ſhall take my bounty too cloſe by
The valley that doth joyne to th' neighbour grove
Lyes conquerd by my ſword a Millain knight,
His wounds medcin'd, & ſtopt by the beſt art
I had, but by much loſſe of blood unable yet
To move, him, and his ranſome I beſtow on you,

sp.speaker: Uaſ.
sp.l: I thank your Lordſhip

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: But uſe him nobly Uaſco; for he hard
A courage that well merited his cauſe,
And fought with eager and with ſsillfull, ſtrength
To free that lady from my bonds, but the glad day was mine.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: He ſhall be kindly us'd,
Only your ſweet lordſhip muſt give me leave
When he pay's his ranſom to weigh his gold,
Were he my father, ſir, he muſt indure
The tryall of my ſcales; follow Triſtan.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Make haſte; ſee him well waggond, and provide
A ſurgeon to attend his cure.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Sir, can you find no pitty yet within
Your breaſt? you have already ſhewn enough.
Of your ſterne fathers ſpirit, is there not
In all your heart ſo much of ſoftnes as
Declares you had a mother too, muſt I
Be led a captive, land in a cruell land
Lament your victorie?

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Alteſto, be are her from my ſight? make haſte?
I am not ſafe, when I converſe with teares.
I would ambition were not brave in war?
Or that the rage of Princes had not made
It lawfull to ſubdue whom they diſlike,
Or 'twere ignoble to inflict a miſerie,
As to indur't our ſelves; Frivolo, where
Didſt thou leave the prince?

sp.speaker: Friv.
sp.l: In purſuit of the Duke, who ſince we heare
Recovered Millaine, which cauſs'd him ſound us.
A retreat,—heark ſir, his march leades hither;
It is his way to Turin.
The prince, the prince; my Lord Proſpero
You have been ſought for, the valiant prince
For this day's action hath advunt'd you to
The publique eare, and we your friends rejoyc'd.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: I did but as his bold example gave
Me fire; I ſaw him conquer kill, and leade
In fetters ſad Faces, which I 〈…〉
Before, and I beleev'd 'twas good; I wiſh
That heaven may thinke ſo too; I do converſe
VVith bookes, but I have heard our enemies
(Although they wrong'd not me) muſt be ſo us'd.
sp.stage: Enter Alvaro, Soldiers ſtripping off his Corſlet.
sp.l: Vnbuckle Calladine, the day is hott,
And our great buſineſſe cooles like to their heates,
That fled to humbled Millaine, & have leſt
Their fainting honour hovering over our creſts,
Leade on my horſe in triumph; I will march
On foot, he hath perform'd his worke, as he
Had equall'd me in ſence of what he did.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Sir, Proſpero the Count, whom your kind feares
So heartily inquir'd for i'th retreat

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Paſſe noble youth, and let me hold thee neere
My heart, joyne thy ſtout breſt to mine that we
May grow a while together in our love,
Yet when divided, be the ſame in thought
And act, this day then haſt begot an hiſtorie,
And given our Savoy Chronicles a theame
To teach them boaſt, and be beleev'd

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Alvaro? my dread Prince; why ſhould you loſe
Your prayſe on me, that did but imitate
The fainteſt of your vigour, and your skill?
You bred mee from my childhood to doe things
That they call glorious, though (dull and much unlearnd)
I cannot teach the cauſe of what I doe,
More than your example, and command.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Since thou gott'ſt ſtrength to weare a ſword, thou haſt
Been mine, and t'hath been drawn to execute
My will, and though (I know not why) thou waſt
A verſe to arts, and written labours of
The wiſe, yet diſcipline of warre thou lov'dſts
And bring thee to a 〈◊〉 ſteed, him thou
VVouldſt ſit, and mannage with ſuch gentle rule
That our Idolatrous Philoſophers
Beleev'd thou hadſt created, whom thou I caught'ſt

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Your love will breed me envy ſir; ſomething.
I've done (ſince you are pleas'd to vallew ſo
My weaker toyles) which may perhaps deſerve
Your fathers thanks, and yours, and's yet unknown
Vnto you both, Evandra, heir of Millaine,
I have ſought for, tane priſoner, and ſent
To Turin, a reward for our juſt war.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Hah! the faire Evandra made priſoner?
And Proſpero by hee?

sp.speaker: Proſ
sp.l: Why ſhould you thinke him whom you prais'd
So much, unfit for ſuch a victorie.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Now all the bleſſings of my faithfull love
Are loſt; ſhe whom I doated on with my
Moſt chaſt, and early apetite, is ſent
In bonds, t'apeaſe my cruell fathers wrath.

sp.speaker: Call.
sp.l: My Lord, he lov'd her much though temp'rately
Conceald from gen'rall knowledge, and his friends.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Then mount my courſer Frivolo, and try
If by the happy quickneſſe of his ſpeed,
Thou canſt recover her returne, and uſe
Her with ſuch faire reſpective homage as
May expiate my violent ſurprize.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Fly, fly; I would thy nimble motion could
Oretake the arrow from th' Aſſyrian bow,
Or ſwifter lightning whom our fight purſues
And is to ſlow to reach.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: What have I done, that I ſhould thus miſtake
An act of valiant glorie, for a deed
That argues an auſtere Ignoble rage?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Faire Evandra, the pide of Italy,
In whom the Graces met to rectifie
Themſelves, that had not cauſe enough to bluſh
Vnleſſe for pitty they were not ſo good
As ſhe; think now the Eaſterne ſpices ſweet,
And that the bloſſoms of the ſpring perfume
The morning ayre; neceſſity muſt rule
Beliefe, lets ſtrew our Altars with them now,
Since ſhe's impriſond, ſtifled, and chok'd up
Like weeping Roſes in a ſtill, whoſe Inarticulate breath
Heaven through a purer ſacrifice than all our orizons.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Is ſhe not fitter then
For Turin, than for Millaine ſir? I ſaw
You take priſoners, and in my fury had
Diſcretion to atchieve the beſt.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: O thou haſt loſt my heart; hence doth proceed
This recreant act, that to thy ſavage courage
I could never joyne the temperature
Of ſweet Philoſophy; hadſt thou been learnd,
And read the noble deeds of gentle knights,
Reaſon had check'd thy rage, thy vallor would
Have been more pittifull than to have lead
A virgin into harſh captivity.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: I thought I had done well.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: How! well? draw back that falſhood in thy breath
Agen, or I will pierce thy heart, that thou.
Mayſt dye Impenitent.
sp.stage: Drawes his ſword, Call. ſtayes him.
sp.l: Vnhand me Callandine, I've already met
My better thoughts; why ſhould I waſte my wrath
On ſuch a foreſter? wild as the woods,
Where he ſhould graze with the brute heard, who though they want
Diſcourſive ſoule, are leſſe inhumane farre than he.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: She was the daughter of our greateſt enemie,
And ſo I us'd her ſir.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: A cholerick Beare; or hungry Panther would
Have us'd her with more ſoft remorce; had I
Incounterd her in the mad heate of chace,
In all the fury of the fight, I would
Have taught my angry ſteed the eaſie and
The peacefull motion of a lambe,
She ſhould have ſet his back, ſoft as the ayre,
And in her girdle bridle him, more curb'd
Than in his ſoaming bitt, whilſt I her ſlave,
Walk'd by, marking what haſty flowers ſprung up,
Invited by her eye-beames from their cold rootes;
And this would each true ſoldier do, that had
Refin'd his courage with the ſober checks
Of ſweet Philoſophy.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Would you had taught me ſome Philoſophy
Before I learn'd to fight.
All hope is paſt; ſhe was convey'd in one
Of your ſwift chariots ſir, which it doth ſeem
Alteſto did unhappily oretake,
And ſhe's ere this within our Turnt walls.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Such language and ſuch newes better become
The fatall birds of night, ſo Ravens croke
When they fly ore the manſions of the ſick
And bode their deaths.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Proſpero, ſee me no more,
Th'art a diſeaſe unto my injurd ſight:
Flye to ſome luſtfull coaſt, where none but Goates
And Satyrs live, where the name of virgin is
As ſtrange as this thy cruelty, there thou
Mayſt hope to wander not contemn'd, ſhould I
Behold thy face agen, and let thee live,
My patience would become my vildeſt guilt.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: See, ſir, he weepes; can you indure him mourne
And languiſh thus, whom heeretofore you did
Embrace in the chiefe ranek of love, not mov'd
(Sir) with his teares?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: No more than to behold
The pudled channell overflow; he ſaw
Her weepe, and could indur't; the drops fell downe
Me thinks, as when the pitteous Pelican
Wounds her remorſefull hreaſt.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Sir, have I in one haſty moment, ſo
Farre merited my ruine that no meanes
Is left to winne me to your former grace.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Never, unleſſe thou couldſt reſtore
Evandras liberty, ſhe is ere this
Within my fathers reach, whoſe nature is
Severe, and mortall to her fathers blood,
An ancient vow he tooke, will make her deſtine.
So ſad, I feare to thinke on it, poore Evandra.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: I ſent her in good conduct to my houſe,
VVhere is a cave, ſo art fully cenceld
Within my gardens verge, that not the ſunnes
Moſt prying beames, not humane ſearch
Can ere diſcover it, He hide her there,
Till time and apt convenience can diſpoſe
Her unto Millain.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Fly then, looſe not the ſick hope with ſlow
Purſuit, fate keepe her from my father.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: I • ſtrive to groane away my breath, and die.

sp.speaker: Frivo.
sp.l: Heark ſir, the Duke your father ſure
Doth ride in triumph through the towne, to meete
And celebrate your victorie.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Give order that our troops march, march ſlowly on;
Our Drums ſhould now in fable caſes beate
Our collours ſoulded, and our Muskets be
Reverſt, whilſt our dejected pikes we traile,
But that I feare, t'would breed inquirie in
My father of a cauſe, he muſt not know,
O Callandine Evandra is in bonds.
sp.stage: Exit. Enter Vaſco, Triſtan, Leonell wounded and led.

sp.speaker: Vaſco.
sp.l: Prepare the waggon Triſtan, ſpread a matt in 't
And (doſt here) bid my Ancient teare of's collors
For a coverlet, tis thine ſir, all our ſhift?

sp.speaker: Triſt
sp.l: All's ready ſir, ith bottom of the hill,
He ſhall us'd like a Queen when ſhee lyes in.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Softly Triſtan, he moves as weakely as
His ſinnewes were of ſpinners threads, ſo cutt
And carv'd; he hath made your skin, ſir, only
Fit to be worne in ſummer; this Proſpero
Is a Turke when's whinyards drawne, and ſhines in's eyes.

sp.speaker: Leonell
sp.l: He us'd me nobly ſir, when I had bled (could
My ſelfe paſt ſtrength to conquer him, wee
I hope to finde ſuch mercy in an Enemie,
Leſſe I had fallen beneath the force of your
Alvaro, Prince of Piemont.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: I there's a man; tis true, Lord Proſ. poro vallant,
I thinke he dares meet the devill in Duell,
And give him two flaſhs of lightning odds, but
He wants that they call learning ſir, Prince Alvaro;
Is (as they ſay) a philoſopey man:
He takes of Rabins, and ſtrange Hebrew roots;
Things we dull Souldiers hither learn then mention.

sp.speaker: Triſt.
sp.l: He can tell you ſir how many ſhowers fell
Since Noahs flood.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: I, and how many cloakes thoſe ſhowers have wett.

sp.speaker: Leonell.
sp.l: Have you no knowledge of the Lady ſir
That was ſurpriz'd from my protection by young Proſpero?

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Good; was ever creature of heavens making
So libidinous as paltry man? now
Has he a mind to the Lady? ſhe ſir,
Is ſafe in Turin, whither ſtrait we mean
To lead you too.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Some comfort yet, it is decreed I muſt
Indure my bondage where ſhe ſuffers her's,
Poore Evandra's was fater ſo niggardly
She could allow no more protection for
Thy beauty than my ſingle fortitude?

sp.speaker: Triſt.
sp.l: Come move on ſir, it will be late ere we
Shall reach the towne.

sp.speaker: Leon
sp.l: What other for tune had the bat taile?

sp.speaker: Veſ.
sp.l: We ſwadled your Duke home he and the reſt
Of your bruis'd countymen have woundrous need
Of capon's greaſe.

sp.speaker: Leon
sp.l: Strange giddineſſe of warre; ſome men muſt groane
To further others mirth, what furie rules
Ore humane ſence, that we ſhould ſtruggle to
Deſtroy in wounds, and rage, our life, that heaven
Decreed ſo ſhort? in is a myſterie
Too ſad to be temembred by the wiſe,
That halfe mankind conſume their noble blood,
In cauſes not belov'd, or underſtood.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: You have heard the proclaim'd law Vaſco.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: I would there were no law, or that no man
Were learn'd enough to read em, or that we had
Courage enough not to obey them

sp.speaker: Triſt.
sp.l: Frivolo, what law is this?

sp.speaker: Friv.
sp.l: It is proclaim'd all female priſoners
After a yeare ſhould have free libertie
To returne to Millaine, and ranſomleſſe.
Only a yeare is given to us the conquerors,
That thoſe we took of birth, and dowry may
(If we can wooe them to conſent) marry us,
But wee have no power to uſe conſtraint, nor to
Inforce a maidenhead, on paine of death.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: My beldam hath tane order with her maidenhead
Ten yeares ere I was borne.

sp.speaker: Friv.
sp.l: I'th meane time Triſtan,
As a requitall for our hopes, we muſt
Maintaine them at our own charge?

sp.speaker: Triſt.
sp.l: Muſt not the men wee tooke pay ranſome?

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Yes, yes, they pay: I have a Knight given me
By young Count Proſpero ſhall ſell his ſpurrs
Ere he ſcape free, I will pawne him till he
Be worne toth' title of a Squire.

sp.speaker: Frivo.
sp.l: Thou art as cruell as a Conſtable
That's wak'd with a quarrell out of his firſt ſleepe.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Hang him bold Caraian, hee indites finely;
And will live as well by ſending ſhort Epiſtles
Or by th'ſad whiſper at your gamſters elbow
When the great by is drawne, as any baſhfull
Gallant of em all.

sp.speaker: Triſt.
sp.l: But whats the cauſe our Duke is ſo ſevere
Unto the heire of Millain (whom 'tis ſaid
Shall ſuffer inſtant death) yet is thus kind
To others of her ſex.

sp.speaker: Frivo.
sp.l: She dies to ſatiſfie
A vow hee made in's youth, when thoſe of Millain
Took his brother priſoner, and would not be
Appeaz'd without the for feiture of's head.

sp.speaker: Triſt.
sp.l: I am not yet inſtructed Frivolo,
VVhy ſhould not then the reſt we took dy too?

sp.speaker: Frivo.
sp.l: Evandra is a ſacrifice for all;
His other mercy takes from th'crueltie
He ſhowes on her.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: From whence Alteſto comes your loftineſſe?

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: Why, from the Duke; I had laid me
For breakfaſt a fine comfortable ginne.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: VVhat was't, a wench?

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: A rack Vaſco, a rack;
A certaine Inſtrument that will extend, and draw
Our ſinnews into treble ſtrings, and ſtretch
Our great ſhinne bones, till they become ſlender
As knitting needles, or a Spiders leggs.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Didſt thou commit Treaſon? 'tis well thou haſt
A braine for any thing, the age requires
Parts, we cannot eat elſe; but quick, the cauſe.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: 'Twas to diſcover where I left Evandra,
VVhom Proſpero deliver'd to my charge;
I anſwer'd a full truth, that I reſtor'd
Her to his hands, at his returne to's houſe,
And this (as fortune would vouchſafe) the Duke
Beleev'd without applying (Gentlemen)
The recreation of the rack.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: But ſhe is not yet found.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: No, and the Duke beleeves her ſtill I'th Town.
Therefore a guard is plac'd at all the gates to hinder her eſcape.

sp.speaker: Vaſco.
sp.l: I do not like
This cutting off young wenches heads; 'tis thought
They cannot kiſſe hanſomely without them.

sp.speaker: Triſt.
sp.l: But how does Proſpero excuſe her flight?

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: He ſaies ſhe's ſtoln away, but ſhews no manner how;
And th' angry Duke, though he be precious in
His love, threatens him much.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Some Angell ſtole her from him, and Gentlemen
If I have any skill in Magick you
Shall ſee her three daies hence pirking in a Cloud,
Southward of yonder Star; look up, juſt there;
With her Ivory Lute hanging at her back,
And working me a ſcarfe of sky-colour'd Sattin.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: A halter (Vaſco) to ſave the poore State
The charge of a penny, thou'lt have need on't.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: What's become of Melora, your faire priſoner?
You heare the Proclamation.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: Yes, and am well pleas'd, I meane to wooe, and marry her, ſhe hath
Twelve thouſand crowns by good intelligence.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: If ſhe conſent; but I am of the faith,
Such Suckets are but ſeldome ſwallow'd by
Us wealthy Aldermen o'th Campe; a joynture
Is the word Alteſto, and then you'l ſhew her
A young back with a Sword hanging over't,
Worſe than a handſaw.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: Juſt now I left her at my mothers houſe;
And ſirra Vaſco, ſhe looks, oh rogue, rogue!
A Flanders peake i'th middle of her brow,
Which ſtraight I ſpy, and ſhake, and melt, then ſpeak
Fine language to her, and am dutious with
My Bonnet at her Inſtep thus—

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Th'aſt ſound the way.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: Then Vaſco ſhe moves back, diſcovering but
The very verge of both her picked toes,
But in white Shoes, and then I'm taken that
I ſtand like one of the Turkes chidden mutes,
A girle in a Bongrace thus high may raviſh me.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Alas poore Gentleman!

sp.speaker: Alteſt
sp.l: But Vaſco, her fiugers, by this good day,
I think they are ſmaller than thy point tags,
And ſhe behaves them on the Virginaſs
So prettily, I'ld wiſh no more of he ven,
Than once to hear her play Fortune my Foe:
Or John come kiſſe me now.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Thoſe are tunes my old widdow priſoner ſings
With more diviſion than a water work
When the maine pipe is halfe ſtopt.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: You have a yeare allow'd to wooe her Vaſco.

sp.speaker: Triſt.
sp.l: She's rich; I knew her husband, he thriv'd much
By a monopoly he had of dead womens hair,
All Millaine talk'd of it; ſhe kept another ſhop
Under St Maudlins wall, and quilted uſhers Calves.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Well Gentlemen, let's waſte no time, I'le to
My Barbers ſtraight, purge, ſhave, and waſh, for know
If cleaneneſſe and good looks will do't Ile teach
Her Grandameſhip to mump, and marry too,
Or my arts faile; Frivolo, you and Triſtan
Follow me, I ſhall employ you both.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: I am for Proſpero, he ſent to ſpeak with me.
sp.stage: Enter Alvaro, Proſpero (with a Key, and Lights.)

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Sir, you have made me know my cruelty,
'Twas ſuch incomely valour, that I bluſh
To name't, and truſt me, could I ſink low as
The Center whileſt I kneel, ſtil would I thus
Implore your pardon, and your love. Kneels

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Ariſe, I have a memory ſo apt
T'advance my pitty 'bove my anger when
It mentions thee, that Ile forget the cauſe
That made thy guilt, and me to mourne; but O,
This diſmal place brings it again to thought,
This lookes methinks like to the dark
And hidden dwelling of the winds, as yet
Unknown to men, where ſtorms ingender, and
The whirling blaſts that trouble Nature till
She tremble at their force, and ruine all
The ſumptuous piles of Art.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Neceſſity hath caus'd this choice, till the
Severe inquiry of your Father be
Appeas'd, and we can ſhape her a diſguiſe fit to
Convey her from the Towne.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: VVith ſoft and gentle ſummons call, that ſhe
May clime unto the top, and verge o'th cave.

sp.speaker: Prof.
sp.l: Evandra ſpeak, aſcend to us; I am
Your penitentiall Enemy, that come
To weep away my treſpaſſe at your feet.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Evandra, riſe, break from this thick
And ſilent darkneſſe, like the eldeſt light.
sp.stage: The Stage opens, Proſpero lifts Evand. vn.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Ha! my Lord the Prince?

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: O noble mind, what expiation can
Make fit this young and cruell Souldier for
Society of men, that hath defir'd
The Genius of triumphant glorious war
VVith ſuch a rape upon thy I berty?
Or what leſſe hard than marble of
The Parian Rock, canſt thou beleeve my heart,
That nurc'd and bred him my Diſciple in
The Campe, and yet could teach his valour no
More tenderneſſe than injur'd Scythians uſe
VVhen they are vex'd to a revenge? but he
Hath mourn'd for it, and ſure Evandra thou
Art ſtrangely pittifull, that doſt ſo long
Conceale an anger that would kill us both.

sp.speaker: Evand.
sp.l: Sir, I am nobly recompenc'd, in that
You will vouchſafe me worthy of your grief,
And though I dye forgotten here (a poore
And luckleſs maid) loſt like a bloſſome which
Th' injurious wind buries in duſt, yet ſo
Much courteſie deſerves to be remembred even in heaven.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Was this a ſubject fit to beare the pride
And inſolent calamity of war?
As well had it become in the worlds youth
The Giant Race, to hunt with mighty ſpeare
And iron ſhield, the ſoft and tender Ermine;
Evandra, I have lov'd thee much, and long.
Why doſt thou ſtart, as if ſome jealous thought
Did whiſper that my love devis'd this ſnare
To keep thee here within my power and reach?

sp.speaker: Evand.
sp.l: I cannot think you are ſo cruell to
Your ſelf, t' afflict the thing that you eſteem.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: No beautious maid, had I behold thy flight
In our ſterne exerciſe of wrath, I would
Have made the bloudy field a garden fit
I' adorne the ſhews of a triumphant peace;
And ev'ry ſoldier like a reaper cloth'd,
Fitter to uſe his ſickle than his ſword.
Still thou recoyl'ſt like the chaſte Indian plant, at the
That ſhrinks and curles his baſhfull leaves,
Approach of man.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: I've loſt my reaſon, and I want the courage
To entertaine you kindneſſe as I ought.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Is it becauſe my yeares a little have
Oregrowne my youth, or that the enmity
Our Fathers interchange begetts in thee
A factious hate, till't make thy duty ſinne?
But tis not poſſible thou canſt create
A thought will merit ſuch a name.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: The gentle buſineſſe ſir of love is fit
For howers more calme, and bleſt than thoſe
A captive can injoy.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Theſe are not words
To quiet me in ſleepe, & peacefull thoughts.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Nor ſhall I evermore relliſh delights
And triumphs of the court, or haughty joyes
Of warre and victorie.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Evanara live, be yet ſome happineſſe
Vnto thy ſelfe, and with the patience that
Becomes a maids divinitie, relieve
Thy heart with eaſie hope of libertie,
Inforcing a content within this darke
And ſolitarie cave, till I have power
With apt diſguiſe to further thy eſcape,
Which ſhall be haſtned with my ableſt skill.
Beleeve me good Evandra, the honour of
My birth and ſoule ſhall warrant it.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: You are a Prince renound, and precious for
Your faith, and courteſie.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Thinke not Ile uſe advantage, or conſtraint
Vpon thy love, a virgins heart (I know)
Is ſooner ſtrok'd than check'd into a kind
Surrender of her breaſt.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Sir, all the bounties that the heavens provide
For truth and clemency, fall on your ſtill.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: If thou ſuſpect'ſt I've not enough of cold
And holy temper to reſiſt the flames
Of appetite, command that I ſhall ſee
Thee here no more, & my obedience ſtraite
Shall be reſtraind within a ſacred vow,
For I would have thy thoughts (Evandra) ſafe
As thy beauties are.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: It were a crime
Greater (I hope) than I ſhall ere commit
To doubt ſuch princely goodneſſe can pervert it ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Then I ſhall cheriſh oportunities
To haſten my returne.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Not Angells ſure when they converſe, can meet
VVith leſſe intent of ſinne, and more of joy?

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: VVell, I muſt ſee thee oft, thy wondrous eyes
Have ſoftned all my ſpirits to a calme
And eaſie temper for thy ſway, that I
Could change my corſlet, and my iron veſts
Of rugged war, to move in gentle pace,
Vnto the tunefull whiſpers of thy Lute,
Still cloth'd in tender garments of thy work,
And for a plumed Helmet weare chapletts
Of flowers, in a myſterious order rank'd
By thy white virgin hand, theu like thy neat
Ore'buſie maid, bind up thy looſer philetting,
And pleate in curles thy ſoft diſhevelld haire.
Ile make my frequent viſits here till thou
Confeſſe how much I am ſubdu'd.

sp.speaker: Evand.
sp.l: I am oppreſt with feare, the watchfull Duke
Your father ſhould obſerve, unto this ſad
Vnuſuall place, your ſtolne approach, & then
My ſorrowes would be doubled in your danger.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Danger? how noble lovers ſmile at (ſuch
A thought? 'tis love that onely fortifies
And gives us mighty vigor to attempt
On others force, and ſuffer more than we
Inflict; would all the ſouldiers that I leade
In active war, were lovers too, though leane,
Feebled, & weakned with theit ladys frowns;
How when their valours ſtirrd, would they march ſtrong,
Through hideous gulphs, through numerous herds
Of angry Lyons, and conſuming fire?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: What doubtfull noyſe is that?

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: 'Tis Colladine, I did appoint him here.
Stay Proſpero, let him not enter yet;
O envious chance, muſt we depart ſo ſcone?
sp.stage: They put Evendra downe in the cave.
sp.l: Deſcend like the bright officer of day,
Whilſt darkned we thy beauteous abſence mourne,
And every flower doth weepe till thy returne?
sp.stage: Opens the doore, lets in Calladine.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: His looks declare there's hazard, and ſome haſte.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: What wouldeſt thou? ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: The Duke your father (ſir) is much perplext;
He calls for Proſpero, and it is feard,
Will torture him to find Evandra's flight.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: He ſhall not yet appeare; I will indure
His angers edge with venture of my ſelfe.
Stay till I ſend.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: My Lord, I grieve to ſee your ſorrowes beare
So great a weight, as makes you groane unto
Your ſelfe; this ſilence, and fixation of
Your eyes, untill unchanged objects cauſe
Them ake, is much unlike your wonted mind;
Suſpect not but the Prince will qualifie
His Father to a peace, and a more juſt
Interpretation of your worth.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Know Calladine, 'tis not Evandras bonds,
Nor all the torments that th' incenſed Duke
From cruelty or art can miniſter,
Have power to freeze, and fixe me like a ſtatue thus;
I have another cauſe that ſwels my heart,
Till 't grow too ſpacious for my breaſt.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: 'Las ſir! your favours have oblig'd me ſo
That I muſt ſhare your griefe, and 'twould perhaps
Afferd ſome remedy to ſhare the cauſe.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I know not Calladine in the vaſt world
One I more love, or would ſo boldly truſt;
But thou wilt think me mad.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: My Lord, Ile forget then my manners, and
My reaſon too.

sp.speaker: Pro
sp.l: Come, thou ſhalt know, I love—
How wilt thou ſmile to ſeem ambitious eyes
Looke higher than the Eagle, when he ſoares
To elevate his ſight? I love—

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Who is't you love?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Evandra; now mixe pitty in thy ſcorn.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: 'Tis ſad the Prince and you ſhould meet with ſo
Much violence in the ſame choice.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: At firſt, i'th rage of fight, I gaz'd on her,
With halfe diſcernings of her forme, a mi ••
Of fury hung between us then, but ſince
That I have viewd her beauty with ſome care,
And ſeen how ſweetly ſhe demeanes her in
Calamity, I have orethrown my heart
With liking her too much.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: It will require great wiſdome to perſwade
In this, the cauſe is dangerous.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Would I had nere been born, then I had miſs'd
The ſight and memory of her, and my
Fond errors ſhould have been as much unknown
As m' uncreated ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: My Lord, your ſervant gave me entrance with
Command that I ſhould ſpeake with you.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: 'Tis true; Alteſto y'have a maiden priſoner,
Call'd Melora; 'tis my requeſt that you
Conduct her hither in diſguiſe; though law
Newly proclaimd, allow no ranſome for her,
You ſhall be paid your own demand.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: Ile obey your Lordſhip, ſhe ſhall attend
You ſtraight; what uſe can he imploy her to?

sp.speaker: Proſp.
sp.l: Come Calladine, eaſe me with thy counſell.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Is Lelia your own priſoner Triſtan?

sp.speaker: Triſt.
sp.l: The powerful purchaſe of my ſword.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: What is ſhe heire to? a braſſe thimble, and
A skeane of brown thread? ſhe'l not yeeld thee in
Algiers above a ducket being ſtrip'd;
And for her clothes they'r fitter for a papermill
Than a Pallace.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Let her ſerve your captive widdow.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Why Triſtan, that's a yeares wages for you;
'Tis well thought on; will you ſerve Lelia?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: I hope ſir I ſhall be fit to ſerve.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Yes, ſerve for an Hoſpitall, when the ſins
Of the Campe are retir'd into your bones;
She's vilely out of Linnen.

sp.speaker: Triſt.
sp.l: How can I help't?

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Let her make love to a Sexton, and ſteale ſhrowds.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Truſt my knowledge Vaſco, ſhe's for thy turne,
Preſent her to thy widdow, ſhe may wooe
In thy behalf, toſte plum cakes for her Muſkadine,
And bruſh her velvet hood on holy-dayes.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Triſtan convey her to her as my gift;
But Lelia you muſt ſpeake notable words
Of me, firſt what a goodly man I am;
That I get Matrons at a hundred and ten
VVith double Twins, and how in time of warre
I fill up the muſter with mine own Iſſue.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Marry ſir, heaven forbid.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: D'you heare? this wench has been villanouſly
Ill bred; and Ile lay my life
She ſings at her work too the holy caroll
O'th Ladies daughter converted in Paris;
She was of Paris properly, &c.

sp.speaker: Triſt.
sp.l: Fie Lelia, you muſt now take care, you are
Not now i'th Campe, but in a civill Common wealth.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: I ſhall endeavour ſir to learne.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Nor muſt you perſwade you Miſtris riſe
Too early to her beads, ſhe may catch cold,
Having already a peſtilent cough,
And ſo will dye before I marry her.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: I hope I ſhall not be ſo miſchievous.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: VVell Gentlemen, the fruitfull houre is now
Drawn neere that gives ſucceſſe, this morning muſt
Expoſe me to great charge.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Thou doſt not meane
To court her at her window with rare muſick?

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: No, ſhe's very deafe, ſo that coſt is ſav'd.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: What other charge? ſhe hath no teeth ſit for
A dry banquet, and dancing ſhe is paſt,
Unleſſe with crutches in an Antimaſque.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: I muſt provide her Culleiſes, and Broths
That may ſtir metall in her, in this caſe
She is, know my good friends, I find
Her no more fit for the buſineſſe of encreaſe,
Than I am to be a Nunne.

sp.speaker: Triſt.
sp.l: Thou wilt take care to trim thy perſon.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: I came juſt now from conſultation with
My Barber, who provides me a large maine,
A lock for the left ſide, ſo rarely hung
With Ribbanding of ſundry colours ſir,
Thou'lt take it for the Rainebow newly criſp'd
And trim'd, Bucephalus nere wore the like.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: VVhen you have reach'd Sir Leonels Ranſome,
And the rich widdows wealth, we are forgot,
Like creatures of Japan, things hardly to
Be ſearch'd for in the Map.

sp.speaker: Triſt
sp.l: In one ſhort month I ſhall not know his name.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: 'Tis then becauſe thou canſt not read, for thou
Shalt find it fairely carv'd on each new Church
And Hoſpitall, I meane to build apace,
And have my blew boyes March through the ſtreets
Two and two, provided for in guilded Primmers,
And their chops of mutton; go haſte to the widdows,
Preſent your Damſel, Ile be with you ſtraight;
My captive Knight would ſpeak with me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I am bold ſir to make free uſe of your
Moſt ſpacious roomes for benefit of aire.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Sir you are welcome, 'tis a liberty
That I expect, and I joy much your wounds
So proſper in their cure.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: You ſhew your inclination kind and noble:
But is there of Evandra yet no newes?
You promis'd to enquire whether her flight
Be true, or to what place ſhe made eſcape.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: No certaintie is known, but all the Court
Troubled with doubts, ſhortly you will heare more.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: If you could bring me ſir to Proſpero,
Or to the Prince, on ſome affaires that may
Perhaps advantage them, and my own good,
You ſhall oblige me much to ſerve you in
My better ſtate of fortunes

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: I will endeavor it, and as you find
Me ready to aſſiſt all your requeſts,
I hope ſir, youle ſee cauſe to pay your ranſome
With what haſte you can, for I would faine be able
To doe good deeds, & we have many poore
I'th towne that want their charitie, who have
A will as ready as their wealth.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Beleeve me you expreſſe a ſoule that hath
Been bred, and exercis'd in holy thoughts.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Faith ſir not much, only you know a man
Would joy to doe ſome good whilſt he's alive,
For after death our gifts I ever thought
Rather proceeded from a devout neceſſity,
Than any free deſire.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Tis wiſely urg'd.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: It hath been a maxime I have held long.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And it becomes you ſtill; my ranſome ſhall
Be ſuddenly prepard.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: I thanke you ſir; follow, & Ile procure
You an addreſſe toth' prince or Proſpero.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: If ſhe were fled, her perſon is of ſo
Eſteem'd, and eminent a rate, that ſtraight
Her inſtant reſidence muſt needs be known.
There is much art in theſe affaires; how will
She looke on me, that in ſo great a cauſe
Could ſtrike, or yeeld to angry fate? I will
Indure her ſcornes, as a deſerv'd reward,
Nor ſhould a lovers hopes grow cold becauſe
The Influence that laſt did governe him,
Was ſick, and cold, that deſtiny is gone,
The firmament containes more ſtarres than one.

div.head: Act. 3. Scaena 1.
div.stage: Enter Leonell and Proſpero, (with a light and a key.)

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: It glads me to behold your ſtrength ſo well
Reſtor'd, and ſir, I wiſh the fortune of
My ſword, had met another cauſe, & enemie;
Your ranſome I have paid, and ſo much prize
Evandra's happineſſe, that ſince you make't
Appeare your company will render her
Some quietnes, and joy, in this her ſad
And ſolitarie ſtate, you ſhall both ſee, and ſtay with her.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: From my firſt infancy I tooke my ſpeech
And breeding in her fathers court, and by
My neerenes to her, both in deeds and place
I'th day of fight, you may beleeve I am
Of qualitie enough to be eſteemd and wellcom'd in her miſerie.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Your valour then did ſpeake you more than all
The praiſe your modeſtie can urge,

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: My Lord, it is your gentleneſſe to have
A courteous faith, but I am bold to think
My ſight will comfort her ſo much that ſhe
Will pay you thanks for giving ſo free truſt
Vnto my confidence.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: My kindnes to you I ſhall reſerve
Till happier howers, this ſir, is for her ſake,
That ſhe may have the benefit of your
Approach, retire a while within, that key
When I am gone, will open you a doore,
That leades unto a cave.—
Melora? where art thou? this way, the light
Conducts thee; thou art ſafe.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: How darke, & like the duſty hollownes
Of tombes where death inhabits, this appeares?

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Now you ſhall know the cauſe why I have bought
Your liberty, Evandra, daughter to
Your Millain duke, lyes here impriſond by
The chance of battaile, and thus hidden, and
Reſerv'd, till we can free her by diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: Melor.
sp.l: O ſad diſcoverie of a ſorrow worſe
Than I indure, I hop'd ſhe had eſcap'd.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: I heard that thou wert taken in her traine,
But when the ſtoryes of thy beauty and
Thy vertues reach'd mine eare, I did beleeve
Thou hadſt familiar knowledge of her face
And thoughts.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I know too much of her, to think that Heaven
Could thus permit her languiſh in a Cave.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: None can reſiſt their deſtinie; but good
Melora comfort her, and prethee for
Kind pitty when your converſation ſhall
Beget ſome pleaſant houre, mention my care,
And then my love; for know, ſhe hath ſo wrought
Upon my heart, that truſt me I ſhall melt
Like Tapers overcharg'd with flame, and die;
Wilt thou implore in my behalfe?

sp.speaker: Melo.
sp.l: Your bounties have oblig'd me to performe
My beſt, elſe I were cruell ſir.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Feare no ſurprize, you are ſecure, for twice.
To day, my houſe by ſterne Authority
Was ſearch'd, but vainly they ſuſpect, and ſtrive
To find this hidden dwelling, that no art
Can imitate for ſecrefie and depth.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: will you be gone?

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: I'm ſent for to the Pallace where I'm told
I ſhall endure for this concealement more
Than natures ſtrength can beare, but L've a ſoule
Dares welcome it with ſcorne.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Lend me the light; look, there's Evandra ſir.

sp.speaker: Pre.
sp.l: It is, remember me, that I may live.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: This mingled paſſion of ſtrange griefe and joy,
I can no longer quietly containe;
Hail the moſt beautious virtue of the world.

sp.speaker: Evand.
sp.l: Lov'd Melora, what diſmall chance, more than
My ſorrow can digeſt, hath brought thee here?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Why am I thought on, or enquir'd for as
A creature that deſerves a life, whilſt you
Remaine within the houſe and armes of death?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: I feare thou art a captive too.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Or elſe the tyranny of war had been
Too much unjuſt; wer't fit you languiſh thus,
And I like to a wanton bird ſhould play
And wing the aire at liberty? and yet
My ranſome's freely paid.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Then tho' art now no priſoner?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: A priſoner to you, or elſe my heart
Were dull, and rudely mannerd to permit
Evandra ſuffer here alone; this war
Hath quickly nurc'd ſtrange Ridles too of love.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Thou doſt complaine with cauſe, 'tis in the Prince.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Another of your Enemies; too much
Of leaſure I ſhall have t'acquaint you with
The accident that brought me to your ſight.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Melora, who is that?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Bleſſe me how miracles increaſe to fright
Aſtoniſhment! ſure there is Magick in
This place; Madam, my Brother Leonel.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Ha Melora? art thou here too? ſuch myſteries
In change ſo ſoon ariv'd I have not read.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: But what unheard of ſtar directed thee
To ſee, and taſte our miſerable ſtate?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Ere I begin the little hiſtory
Of the ſhort time that thus hath varied us,
Low as the earth I full to make you pittifull. Kneeles
For give the crime of deſtiny, not me,
That left me feeble as an Aguiſh girle
With the faint loſſe of bloud, when I had tooke
Upon my youth & ſtrength, the nobleſt cauſe
That ere imployd the anger of a man,
Your liberty; but Leve • ites, and Doves
Are valianter than I, for elſe what make
You in captivity?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Beleeve me ſir, your paſſion is ſo great
I underſtand it not; pray riſe, I know
You fought with all the forward will and might
That humane rage could ſhew, but the ſucceſs
Of valour they above diſpoſe, that are
More wiſe and ſtronger than our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Sure I could weep, but that my eyes
Have not enough of ſunerall dew to melt
Away 〈◊〉 , pray pardon my neglect.
You'l find I am not courteous to my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Melora.
sp.l: The time compells diſtracted thoughts in all.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: There is a banke within, though cold and bare,
Where never flower (in a diſpaire of ſunne)
Durſt fix his root, there we will fit, talke and
Compare our miſeries; then ſing like Philomel.
That wiſely knowes the darkneſſe only fit
For mourning and complaint; leade there the light.
sp.stage: Enter Duke (with letters) Alvaro, Proſpero, Calladine, attendants.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Evade me not with ſuch fond circumſtance,
Fit only to perſwade the eaſineſſe
Of untaught babes; have I not here receiv'd
Her fathers letters, that petition her
Releaſe? why ſhould he ſooth me thus with low
Demeanour in his phraſe, if ſhe were free?
Or if not in the towne inclos'd and hid,
Where would ſhe ſooner fly than to his armes?

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Sir, give my duty boldnes to beleeve
If ſhe were here, & ſome good man (that now
Conceales her in his pittious feare) ſhall to
Aſſwage your wrath deliver her, you would
Nor marke her out for death?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: No ſir, how cheape then, and how fraile will you
Suppoſe my vowes? what need we trick,
And dreſſe our Altars with ſuch reverend care
Lets rather ſtraight pervert their uſe, greaſe them
VVith gluttony, and feaſts, defile and waſh
Them with the riots of exceſſefull wine;
Is perjurie the leaſt of guilt you can
Perſwade me to commit?

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: I wiſh you would allow m' obedience leave
To utter truth; the vow you made was raſh,
And not confirmed with oath, or church ſolemnitie.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: And I am taught the cruelties, or the
Revenge we threaten, heaven is pleas'd when they
Are never acted but forgot.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Her ſterne, and deathed father, when we ſought
And woo'd his mercy with humility,
More than dejected Hermites on their knees
Render to Saints, us'd not my brother with
Remorſe, but ſnatch'd him from the world in all
His pride of youth, his wiſe, and ripened thoughts,
When he was fit to rule a nations fate,
And exerciſe mankind in what was bold,
And good, then ſhall I not revenge the beſt
Of all my blood, whilſt I have here the chiefe of his.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Alas, this act ſir, was not hirs, nor in
The juſtice of our reaſon is it poſſible
By derivation or deſcent to ſhare a guilt.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Would I had loſt the benefit of ſtrength
When I ſurprizd her, to become the inſtrument
And pleaſure of your rage.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How Count? ſo bold? heare me thou ſaucy child
And minion of the war, whom fortune, not
Succeſſe from vertue ſprung, hath liſted to
A pride more dangerous than traytors thoughts,
Though I have ſearch'd thy houſe, & am defeated by
Some charme of my diſcoverie, I ſtill
Beleeve thou know'ſt her reſidence, & bring
Her to my ſight, ere yet the Sun decline, or thou ſhalt die.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: I muſt not live to ſee it then, nor can
My buſineſſe here on earth, intice me to
One minutes ſtay in my mortality,
When I behold your goodneſſe ſo decaid.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Alvaro was that ſaid like one that knowes
His duty to a Father, and a Prince?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: I would be heir unto your vertue ſir,
As well as to your bloud.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Have I outliv'd my courage, office, and
My reaſon too, tamely to ſuffer this?
I know thy falſe ambitious cunning well,
Thou fain wouldſt vexe my weary ſoule away
That thou mightſt raigne, and triumph ore my tombe;
But heare, and tremble at my vow.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Sir, for regard of heaven repent what you
Would ſpeak, ere utter'd it become too great
A ſin for mercy to excuſe.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: No more fond Calladine, I am reſolv'd,
Since thou art covetous to own his guilt,
He ſhall be ſafe, and thou endure his puniſhment;
Bring me Evandra here ere yet the day
Conceale his light, or the next darkneſs ſhall
Eternally be thine

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: If on my knees I can perſwade you to
An eaſier doome, thus I endeavour it.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: I beg not to entreat your rigor leſſe,
But as 'twas firſt deſign'd you would convert
It all on me.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: That kindneſs was ill manner'd Proſpero;
Doſt think thou art more worthy of the cauſe
When 'tis to be Evandra's Sacrifice?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Nere ſtrive, thou ſhalt have ſufferance enough,
And gloriouſly, alone; hence from my fight
Thou birth ill gotten, and my marriage ſtain.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Ile keep my duty ſtill, though not your love.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Dread ſir, call back your vow, and then the Prince,
Yet comfort him; what will the world eſteeme
Of ſuch an act as time nere paraleld,
And no Poſterity be ſo unkind as to believe?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Thou maiſt as well perſwade th'aſſembled winds
From all their violence at Sea; lend me
Thine eare—do this, but Calladine take heed
Thy proſecutions are not faint; I have
A younger ſon in Sicilly, renown'd
And deare to Fame, him I will ſtrive to plant
I'th peoples hearts; as thou are Loyal follow me.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Juſt in the poſture as you ſee me Gentlemen,
Not a haire leſſe i'th Lock; and I beleev'd
The heart of woman was not able to
Reſiſt ſuch amorous formes.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: But ſhe would none?

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Name her the pleaſures of the marriage bed,
She cries ſhe is more taken with the grave,
'Cauſe there we are not wak'd with cough not aches.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: Why ſure ſhe knows, for ſhe looks as ſhe had
Been long buried.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: And then I us'd fine phraſes,
And talk'd (what call you it?) of Hymens Tapers,
Which ſhe interprets ſir, according to
Some modern Doctreſſe of her Sect, Hel fire,
A warmth (you know) we Souldiers do abhor.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: 'Tis baſe to need it after death; we have
Been hardly bred, and can endure the cold. Enter Widow, and Lelia.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: She comes, this is her breathing roome, uſe your
Endeavours Gentlemen; tell her, her frowns
Already have ſo wrought, that my life now
Will nere be fit to come into a Leaſe.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Lelia a Chaire, I cannot laſt; 'tis more
Than 58 yeares ſince I had hams to trudge.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: I am your Guardian that come to viſit you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: What need it ſir? I practice no eſcape, I cannot flye.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: No? were the window open
You would behave your ſelfe as nimbly on
Your wings as any witch in Europe.

sp.speaker: Wid
sp.l: What ſaies he Lelia, a witch?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: He ſaies we muſt one day all flye upward,
Heaven is the place we wiſh for.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: 'Tis well ſaid ſir, for thither we muſt go,
Both old and young, no remedy.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: As ſoone as you pleaſe if you'r but marry me.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Does he talk of marriage?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: He ſayes, if you pleaſe for ſooth.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Alas my vow of widowhood is not yet
Expir'd; if he comes ſome ten yeares hence—

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: About that time ſhe'l make a good wife
For an Antiquary to get Records on.

sp.speaker: Frt.
sp.l: Although her skin be Parchment, 'tis not large
Enough to write her Annals in, ſn'ath liv'd ſo long already.

sp.speaker: Uaſ.
sp.l: How did you like the cullelſe widow that I ſent you laſt?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Why ſir? It went down.

sp.speaker: Uaſ.
sp.l: Though the Sea were turn'd to plum broth, t'would all down;
I have meaſur'd her throat, 'tis wider (gent.)
And deeper than a well; alas the Duke
Conſiders not my charge, I'ld rather boold
Too Young Giants, and allow each of them
A wolfe in ſtead of a dog t'eat) their fragments.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: Thou ſhouldſt get her month ſearch'd, I'le lay my life
Sh'ath new furniſh'd her gummes with artificiall teeth,
She could not grinde ſo elſe.

sp.speaker: Friv.
sp.l: Though you muſt ſeede her at your owne coſt, the proclamation
Beleeve me allowes none but naturall teeth.

sp.speaker: Uaſ.
sp.l: When ſhe is once i'th fit of ſwallowing,
If a cap on float in her broth, why ſhe
Conſiders it no more than a ſmall bee, or a May fly.

sp.speaker: Lelia.
sp.l: You ſhould beare up, you are too backward ſir.

sp.speaker: Uaſ.
sp.l: Sayſt thou ſo wench; widow prepare your ſelfe,
For I muſt marry you to night, or elſe
You faſt to morrow; if the Duke will not
Afford us faſting dayes, I ſhall make bold
To borrow em o'th Kalender; this night;
No longer time to delay a good deed.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Vh, uh, uh.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: This cough (Vaſco) is of ſome great antiquity.
How wilt thou ſleep by her?

sp.speaker: Frivo.
sp.l: A little Opium after ſupper, and let her cough like a
Cannon from a ſort, I'le free thee from waking.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Come, come, provide; trimme up your hood widow.
And ayre your petty coates i'th ſunne, it is
A caſe of conſcience Gent. we muſt
All marry, and live chaſt.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Why ſir, if we muſt needs.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: I thought ſhe would conſent; good heart; it is
As towardly an old thing. Deare Vaſco,
Provide us muſick, wee'l dance her to death:
Thou ſhalt be her husband ere night, and her
Executor before morning.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Sooth Gent. that's all I deſire,
Any thing, that is reaſon contents me.

sp.speaker: Friv.
sp.l: Go, kiſſe her, by this hand a Browniſt (is
More amorous; a notch'd premice a very
Aretine in compariſon of thee.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: By your leave widow.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Much good may't do you ſir; theſe comforts come
But ſeldome after foureſcore, the world (indeed)
Is grown ſo wicked that we never thinke
Of comforting one another.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: I told you ſhe would ſoften ſir; alas,
A little raw, and modeſt at the firſt.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: A very green pippin of the laſt yeares growth.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: You ſhall finde me a kind of ſparrow widow,
A barly corne does as much as a potatoe.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Bleſſing on your heart ſir, we ſhould doe good
Freely (as they ſay) without egging on.

sp.speaker: Uaſ.
sp.l: Riſe, and ſtir your feet, 'tis healthfull for you.
There—ſoftly,—ſo—

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: If one of the haires of my eye brow lye
But in her way, ſhe's gone, and falls like an
Elephant, whoſe leggs are cut with a chaine ſhot.

sp.speaker: Friv.
sp.l: Her Os Sacrum needs a little Prop.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Why Gentlemen, ther's nere a wench in Italy
Moves farther in a day, provide her litter
But eaſie, and her two mules well fed.
Courage widow; how is it now?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: A certaine ſtitch ſir in my ſide, but t'will away in time.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: I you are young enough,
But given too much to hoyting, and to barly breake,
Then dance naked till you take cold; good faith
You muſt looke too't Lelia, take heed you aire
Her wedding ſmock.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: Let it be made of Catts skin furre:

sp.speaker: Frivo.
sp.l: Or a watch mans rugge gowne, but that her skin
Will weare it out too ſoone.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Frivolo, yo are too lowde.

sp.speaker: Frivo.
sp.l: I warrant thee I have meaſured her eares,
She heares in diſtance but an inch length.

sp.speaker: Uaſ.
sp.l: You'l in, and ſet the houſe in order widow? I'le fetch a prieſt.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Truly ſir, I'ld faine aske my friends advice,
One that hath ſeen but little of the world
Would be glad you know of counſell.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: No counſell widdow, nay, if you want metall
Let them call't raſhneſſe, our youth will excuſe all.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: VVell Sir, you know where marriages are made,
'Tis not my fault; Lelia, provide a broome
And ſweepe away the rhume neere the green Couch;
And (d' you heare) look for one of my cheek teeth
That dropt under the wanſcore bed.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: And ſhall I ſtop't forſooth with ſalt?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I, and fling't 'ith fire; you are weary ſir?

sp.speaker: Uaſ.
sp.l: No quite ſo luſty (widow) as your ſelfe,
But ſhall keepe pace the journey being ſo ſhort.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: Quick, in with her Uaſco, whilſt the fit holds.

l.hi: With cable and thong he drew her along,
ſo heavily to the Prieſt,
And vow'd to untoe her, ere he did wooe her,
make her up after who liſt.

sp.speaker: Frivo.
sp.l: Ah Rogue, thou art a very Larke in the morning.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: And what at night Frivolo?

sp.speaker: Friv.
sp.l: A very owle.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: Thou art a coxcombe, beyond all redemption
Of wit, leſſe thou ſtraight reſolve to marry Lelia;
Thy friends will think the match ſo fit, none ſhall
Forbid the banes; I knew her mother too:
She's wondrous rich in pewter, ſmall wine caske,
And ſpits.

sp.speaker: Friv.
sp.l: Yes, I have heard o'th wealthy Dowager,
She kept a the ch'd Nunnery in my quarter.

sp.speaker: Triſt.
sp.l: Wher's Uaſca Gentlemen? I am in haſte.

sp.speaker: Alteſt
sp.l: Why then for more diſpatch anſwer you ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Triſt.
sp.l: The Duke hath ſent for him, by Calladine,
Who told me 'twas for buſines of import;
The Court is all diſturb'd, but for what uſe
He is deſignd, I cannot learne; where is he?

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: Follow, wee'l convey thee to him; ſtrange luck;
Sir Leonells ranſome, this widowes wealth,
And now imployd at Court? Uaſco th'art a gon man,
Vſury, furrd gownes, long dinners, and ſhort ſleepes,
Thou art condemd to without help; or hope.
sp.stage: Enter Evandra, Melora, Leonell, (at one dore) at the other Proſpero, (muffled and hid) A Table and lights ſet out, Evandra ſits to reade.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Siſter, where is your tenderneſſe? ſhall I
Be ever loſt through your defect of will
And courage to preſent me to her care
In winning characters? tell her how long
VVith fervencie I have purſued my love.

sp.speaker: Melo.
sp.l: Vnhappy Leonell, why doſt thou tempt
Me with impoſſible deſires how oft
Have I ſollicited thy ſute with a
Repulſe? and ſhe hath charm'd me by a vow
Never to mention's more, till her releaſe.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Falſe Leonell, did I for this aſſiſt
Thee to injoy her lov'd ſocietie,
That thou ſhouldſt rivall me, and have more fit
Convenience for thy wiſhes, than me ſelf?
Melora is his ſiſter too, what ſtrange
New chances have theſe later howers produc'd?
I have no Advocate, nor am I hold
Enough to be mine owne.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I ſee you love me not;
And ſince I am a trouble to your ſight,
Ere long thou ſhalt behold my face no more.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Thou art a Prophet to thy ſelf, and I
Thy Prieſt to cut thee out in Sacrifice,
Although unworthy of Evandras deity.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Melora, can you ſhew no kind remorſe?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Alas, you do miſtake my power and will;
Think on ſome other beauty, for the world
Hath many that may make you fortunate.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: None but Evandra governs in my breaſt.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Her thou ſhalt nere enjoy; lend me thine eare—

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Ha! Proſpero?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Falſe Knight; was this the cauſe
That made thee beg conceal'd admittance here
To practice love where I had planted mine?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: My Lord I underſtood not of your love.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: If thou art bold, and ſince thy vanquiſhment
Darſt tempt a ſecond hazard of my ſword,
Go waite me on the garden mount, there I
Will order, though my heart is doubtfull to
Enjoy Evandras love, thine never ſhall.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I will expect thee there, and fiercely long
To raviſh from thy creſt the honour that
I lent thee in our former fight.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Evandra, reach me thy faire hand that I
Seale on it my laſt farewell.

sp.speaker: Evand.
sp.l: Ha, whither do you go?

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Where ſhadows vaniſh when the worlds eye wincks,
Behind a cloud, and they are ſeene no more;
The place of abſence where we meet (by all
The gueſſe of learned thought) we know not whom,
Only a prompt delight we have in faith
Gives us the eaſie comfort of a hope,
That our neceſſitie muſt rather praiſe than feare as falſe.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: O horrid myſtery! my tender ſenſes are amaz'd▪ I faine
Would learne what it is dangerous to know.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Why do the ſtars neglect us thus? why ſhould
VVe loſe the nobleſt and the beſt of men?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Me thinks my ſpirits climbe and life me to
A valiant envy of his ſufferings.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: That thou mayeſt live here ſafe till Proſpero
Reſtore thee unto liberty and light,
I muſt to darkneſſe go, hover in clouds,
Or in remote untroubled aire, ſilent
As thoughts, or what is uncreated yet:
Or I muſt reſt in ſome cold ſhade where is
No flowry ſpring, nor everlaſting growth,
To raviſh us with ſent, and ſhew, as our
Philoſophy hath dreamt, and rather ſeems
To wiſh than underſtand.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: All this for me; you ſhall not dye; why will
You lay ſo cheape a value on your ſelfe,
To think the world ſhould loſe you for my ſake,
Alas, a needleſſe triviall Virgin that
Can never ſhew in hopefull promiſe halfe
That excellence which you reveale in art?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: It is decreed; Evandra thou mayſt live
T' encreaſe the ſmall example we have leſt
Of vertue, which hath made thy breaſt her throne;
Time hath begun to weare away my youth,
And all the good I can performe is to
Preſerve the future hope of it in thee.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Melora, help, ſorrow hath fild my heart
With ſuch a heavineſſe, that I muſt ſink
Beneath its weight—here let me lye, and mourne,
And chide that haughty deſtiny that thinks
Us ſo unworthy of their care.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: My Lord the Prince, Is it no leſſe than death
Of her, or you, can eaſe your Fathers wrath?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: 'The doome is paſt, and the ſad houre will want
No wings to haſten its approach; come hither Proſpero.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: It muſt not be; though I want phraſe to ſhew
My nature ſmooth, it ſhall appeare in deeds.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: I charge thee by our love, by all my care
That bred thee from thy childhood to a ſenſe
Of honour, and the worthieſt feates of war,
Thou keep Evandra ſafe till happier daies
Conſpire to give her liberty, uſe her
With ſuch reſpective holineſſe as thou
Wouldſt do the reliques of a Saint inſhrind,
And teach thy rougher manners tenderneſſe
Enough to merit her ſociety.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: What need this conjuration ſir? I meane
To dye for her, that I may ſave your life;
A brave deſign, diſſwade me not, though I
Faile oft in choice of fitting enterpriſe,
I know this is becoming ſir, and good.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Thou dye for her? alas poore Proſpero
That will not ſatisfie, the ſhaft aimes here,
Or if it would, I do not like thou ſhouldſt
Thus preſſe into a cauſe that I reſerve
To dignifie my ſelfe; urge it no more.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: VVhat am I fit for then, if not to die.

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: How am I worthy of this noble ſtrife?

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Evandra riſe, that I may ſee ſome hope
And comfort in thy ſtrength, before I take
My everlaſting leave.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: You have the voyce of death already ſir.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Diſmall it ſounds, like the laſt groane which men
In torture breath out with their ſoule.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: I could have wiſh'd I might enjoy thee and
Be mortall ſtill, mix in a love that ſhould
Produce ſuch noble vertues as would ſoone
Entice the Angels to live here, yet not
B'our converſation grow impain'd; but theſe
Are wiſhes made too high, and late to thrive.
For evermore farewell.—

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: O ſir, where will you leave me then?

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: How pittie moyſtens me? there in the Cave.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: It is the manſion Sir of death, ſomething
Horrid as midnight thoughts can forme ſo frights
Me ſtill, I tremble when I enter it.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Ha! what that is but humane dares diſturbe thy quietneſſe?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Sir let me ſee, it dies if it be vulnerable.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Still you uſurpe my Buſineſſe Proſpero—
Bide there, I will go down my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Sir, 'twill not preſently appeare.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: I will attend its ſaucy leaſure then. deſcends the Cave.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Lock ſafe the doore Melora with this Key.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: VVhat's your deſigne? meane you t'impriſon him?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Diſcover (Proſpero) the inſide of
Thy breaſt; doſt thou affect the Prince?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Next to the abſent bleſſings that our faith
Perſwades us to, eternity of joyes.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: VVhy then wilt thou permit that he ſhould taſte
A long forgetfulneſſe in a darke grave?
Let us invent ſome way to eaſe him of
This penance undeſerv'd, and ſuffer it our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: O glorious maid! th's goodneſſe will confer
A dignity for ever on our Sexe.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I'm ſtrangely taken with this virgins thoughts,
Let me embrace your hand upon my knee—
I thank you much, you have ſome mercy on
My dull unknowing youth, and can believe
Me fit for noble enterprize, though he
Unkindly did deny my ſute: Ile to
The Duke and tempt his fury till he cauſe
My death, perhaps when his revenge hath quench'd
Her thirſt with my warm bloud, it may grow cold,
And kindly temperd to you both,
And then I've fully ſatisfied the crime
Of your captivity, and his free ſufferance.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: This Souldier hath a great and daring heart.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: But how ſhall I enjoy her then? I ſcarce
Can underſtand the happineſſe it beares:
Tis odd ambition this, but yet 'tis brave,
He do't: beſides, though I'm not learn'd to know
VVith certainty, yet I have hope I ſhall
Be ſenſible of all her viſits to
My tombe, and ev'ry flower ſhe ſtrewes will there
Take growth as on my garden banks, whilſt I
(Delighted ſpirit) walke and hover 'bout
Their leaves, comparing ſtill their ſent with hers;
O twill be wondrons brave! Lady, diſpatch,
That I may goe, and die.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Since you expreſſe your will, ſo kinde, and violent,
That ſmall proviſion there allotted to
Suſtaine my life, reach up, and ſtraight convay
Into the cave, that he may finde it out,
And not exchange the paine his father would
Inflict, for famiſhment.
sp.stage: Proſ. takes from behind the Arras a bottle and bag, they open the Cave.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: I had almoſt forgot falſe Leonell,
He waits me on the mount, I will be with
Him ſtraight, and end his hopes by a long ſleepe
Ere I begin mine owne.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Once more Melora lock the doore; now they
Are both ſecure, tis thou and I that muſt
Take ſolemne leave, and never meete in this
Our beauty, colour, or our warmth agen.

sp.speaker: Melo.
sp.l: I am aſtoniſh'd at her excellence,
And ſcarce have humble grace enough to keepe
Ambitious envy from my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: VVhy ſhould theſe mighty ſpirits lay ſo vaſt
An obligation on our ſex, and leave
Eternall bluſhes on our ſoules, 'cauſe we
In acts of kinder pitty, and remorſe
(The vertues ſure, wherein we moſt excell)
Durſt not adventure like to them?

sp.speaker: Melo.
sp.l: The Prince deſerves a liberall choice of lives
To ranſome his; would mine would ſatisfie.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: How Melora? I cannot thinke thou doſt
So faintly love my happineſſe, and my
Renowne, to wiſh to hinder me of both.

sp.speaker: Melo.
sp.l: Alas, th'example is ſo good, I faine would follow it.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: But there is reaſon that I ſuffer firſt.
I have a mourning weed within which thou
Shalt dreſſe, and teach me weare, then ſo
Apparelled like my cauſe, I'le walke to'th Duke.

sp.speaker: Melo.
sp.l: O leave me not behind, let me accompany
Your mourning too, perhaps my death may be
Accepted beſt, and you bee thought more fit to live.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Thy inclinations have a noble ſence,
Thou ſhalt along; go, call thy brother in,
And call aloud, this hollowneſſe is ſuch
He will not heare thee elſe.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Hoa, Leonell? my brother Leonell.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Tis ſtrange, this Proſpero appeares not yet,
Sure he is faint, and's aguiſh courage comes
To him by fitts; what is your will?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: If thou doſt love me Leonell (as thou
Haſt ſworn, and with aſſertions moſt devout)
I know there is no ſtrict command I can
Preſent, but thy obedience will performe.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Bring me to triall ſtraight, if I prove weake
Or falſe, I am unworthy to appeare
In the ſuns light, or evermore enjoy
The better influence of your eyes.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Give me confirm'd aſſurance on your knee
That you will execute with reall faith,
And punctuall circumſtance, what I injone.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Let me ſalute your hand, I breath on it my vow.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Now Ile informe thee Leonell; the Prince
And Proſpero are both within the cave,
Shut and inclos'd by us, where hourely thou
Through a ſmall ſlender wicket ſhall't convay
Such food, as a diſguiſed ſervant of
The houſe (who heretofore provided our
Reliefe) ſhal helpe thee to, take here this key
And not permit their paſſage forth, till I
Am gone t'ordaine by death their liberty
Secure, which I will ſuffer to appeaſe the angry Duke.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Furies and Fiends ceaſe on my ſences ſtraight;
What have I promis'd in the raſhnes of
My dull and inconſiderate love?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: If thou doſt break thy vow the curſes of
The Saints, and mine (which dying will not leaſt
Afflict thy perjury) fall on thy heart.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Never be call'd my brother, nor aſſume
The honour of my valiant Fathers name.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Melora come, we are too ſlow in ſuch
An act as will outlive all hiſtory.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: O what a dull inhumane Lover am
I grown! that ſimply by a forward and
Unskilfull duty can conſent the Queene
And Lady of my life ſhould be a Sacrifice
To hinder others deaths? this ſure is ſuch
A great example of a female fortitude
As muſt undo all men, and bluſhing make
Us ſteale from our unjuſt advancement ore
The world; teare off our ſawcy beards before
The ſcatt'ring winds that give us the preheminence
Of Sexe; when this is known let women ſway
Counſels, and war, whilſt feeble men obey.

div.head: Act. 4. Scaena. 1.
div.stage: Enter Calladine (in a night Gowne,) and a Servant.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: A Lady ſayſt thou in a mourning Veſt?
What ſhould this earely viſit meane, ere yet
By full appearance of the Sun we can
Diſtinguiſh day from night?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sir, ſhe importunes much to ſpeak with you,
Saies her affaire asks ſecrecy and haſte.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Retire a while without, and let her in.
Since firſt my eyes had judgement to diſcerne
A meane from excellence, they nere beheld
A beauty ſo ore coming and exact;
What are the lov'd commands you'ld lay on me?
I not remember that I ever ſaw
A face I would more willingly obey;
If it were civill too I'ld aske your name.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Beleeve me gentle Sir when that is known
You'l think me too unfortunate to live;
I am call'd Evandra.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ha! the Princeſſe? wiſely did Proſpero
Preſerve thee from my ſight, thy beauty is
Too great and dangerous for youth to know
And be ſecure; though I nere ſaw her till
This bleſſed houre, yet Fame aſſiſted me
T'imagine an Idea like her ſelfe;
But why have you forſaken your conceal'd
Aboad, and thus adventure into th'view
Of men? I feare it is not ſafe.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: 'Tis to employ your vertue ſir; I know
You love the Prince, though not with ſo devout
A heart as mine; for that I may reſtore
Him unto liberty and's Fathers love,
I here preſent my ſelfe to cruell death.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: This is a valiant piety, a gratitude
That ſhews her mind more noble than her ſhape;
She is not known unto the Duke more than
By gueſſing Characters tane from report;
She muſt not dye; though lately his commands
Have ſingled my allegiance out, it is
Religious ſure to faile in this.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Sir, expectation of the ills we muſt
Endure do more perplex us than the paine
It ſelfe. I crave you'ld not protract my ſufferance.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: My thoughts have faſhiond it unto my wiſh;
Is there not a captive call'd Melora,
(Moſt beautifull and young) that hath of late
Familiar been to your ſociety?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I feare he hath diſcoverd me;
D'you know the Lady ſir?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Only by Proſpero's report, and I
In charity deſire her perſon ſafe;
Your death alone will ſatisfie the Duke.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: My prayers have much endeavor'd that it may;
And Sir t' aſſiſt your kind humanity
Receive this key, 'twill give you entrance where
She now remaines a priſoner by my art;
It is a narrow Cloſſet that ore looks
The Orchard grove; you know the houſe, 'tis Proſpero's.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I am familiar there with all the vaults,
And hidden paſſages.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Sir, for regard of honour ſuffer not
Her freedome from that place, till I am dead,
For ſhe's ſo much delighted with this cauſe,
That with unwilling falſhood I was faine
To take advantage of her orizons,
And whilſt ſhe kneeling lengthned her diſcourſe
With heaven, ſteale on this funerall habit, and
In haſte cloſe up the dore to hinder her
Purſute, where now ſhe ſtays lamenting her
Inforc'd ſecure eſtate, and envying of
This danger which I chearefully embrace.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: My life ſhall warrant hers, be pleas'd to enter there,
And ſtay till I informe the Duke of your appearance and approach.

sp.speaker: Melo.
sp.l: Moſt willingly; but ſtill ſir I implore your mercy would
Secure that Lady, and the Prince, how ere
The angry ſtarrs provide for me.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: It is no leſſe unkind t'importune than
To doubt my care; there Lady, through that doore—
Expect my ſad returne will be too ſoone.

sp.speaker: Melo.
sp.l: Forgive me beſt Evandra, that I thus
Aſſume thy name, and have beguil'd thee of
So brave a death, the motive that perſwades me to't
Did not become thy knowledge nor my tongue.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: This Princeſſe hath a ſoule I could adore
Whilſt it remaines eclips'd on earth, nor ſhall
It yet reach heaven; both being utterly
Vnknowne, will make the plot with eaſy help
Succeed. Melora ſtraight I will preſent
T'appeaſe the fury of the Duke, and then
This Lady and the Prince are free; through blood
Is the beſt iſſue of our hopes; if fate
Ordaine it thus, I ſhall prove fortunate.
sp.stage: Enter Frivolo, Triſtan, Muſitians, and Boy.

sp.speaker: Alteſto.
sp.l: Come boy, lift up your voyce to you 'bay window.
Sing the Song I gave you laſt night, and firke
Your fidles bravely too, beare up the burthen.
