l.hi: No morning red, and bluſhing faire, be through your glaſs, or curtaines ſpyd,
But cloudy gray, as the ſhort hayre, of your old everlaſting Bride.
So old, ſo wondrous old, i'th nonage of Time,
Ere Adam wore beard, ſhe was in her Prime.
Whoſe ſwarthy, dry'd weſtphalia hipps, are ſhrunk to mummie in her skin,
Whoſe gummes are empty, and her lipps, like eyelids hairy and as thin.
So old ſo wondrous old, &c.
For Am'rous ſighs which virgins uſe, ſhe coughs aloud from lungs decayd,
And with her palſey cannot chuſe but ſhake, like th'trembling of a maid.
So old, ſo wondrous old, &c.
And when her nightly labour ſwells, to vaſt extent, her pregnant wombe,
Midwives believe, that it foretells, a hopefull Timpany to come.
So old, ſo wondrous old, &c.
What need her husband then vex heaven, and for a plenteous off-ſpring begge,
Since all the Iſſue can be given, is that which runneth in her legge.
So old, ſo wondrous old, &c.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: Good morrow to the right worſhipfull leader Captaine Vaſco,
And to's his right reverend Bride.
Now gentlemen ſcrapers you may be gone:

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: My good friends, a certaine ſalt ſhower ſhould have
Seaſon'd your feathers, had not my luck bin
To marrie with one that conſumes all her moyſture
In thume, a meere Egyptian cloud for drowth.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: But why ſo ſoone abroad? Vaſco are theſe
A Bridegroomes howres? thou art as early up
As creditors i'th Terme.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Or Sergeants when
The needy gallant meanes to ſteale a journey.

sp.speaker: Triſt.
sp.l: And they prevent it by arreſting his innocent horſe.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Buſineſſe at Court; but Gentlemen this is
A reſurrection to me, beleev't
I'm riſen from the dead, from bones more duſty
Than theirs that did begin their ſleep beneath
A marble Coverlet ſome thouſand yeares ago.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: 'Las poore Vaſco! widdows can ſtrangely mortifie.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Put Dates and Amber in the Gruell Lelia,
And let it boyle long.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: And ſhal I make the Poultice ſtraight, and ſend
Your other hood forſooth to be new lin'd?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Firſt ſtay till you have ript my velvet muffe,
Ile have that lining ſerve.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: She's riſen too; pure ſoule,
Devotion and Aches keep her ſtill waking.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: How do you Sir? we muſt comfort one another.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: There is need of't, no Marriner ere had

A worſ •
• ight in a ſtorme.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: 〈◊〉 is uſage Vaſco wil hardly mollifie
Her Iron Cheſt, and make her bags open.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Nay, I've tane order for her wealth if ſhe
Would be ſo courteous now to dy.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: Beleeve me, you'l find her very obſtinate
Touching that point; 'tis true, a woman that
Had the leaſt dramme of kindneſſe or of reaſon
Would for her husbands benefit depart
This tranſitory at a minutes warning,
Make a low courtſie, take her leave and dy,
With leſſe noiſe than flies forſake us in a froſt.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: I, you ſpeake of kind reaſonable women,
Alas ſhe's of another mould; ſhe'ld think't
A ſtrange requeſt if I ſhould urge it to her,
Though it be evidently for my good.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: What is't for her to dye once? alas,
She knows well ſhe hath eight lives more to come.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: Frivolo ſaies right. I think Captaine 'twere fit
You make a motion to her; ſee how 'twill worke.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Never Gentlemen; if her own good nature
Will not perſwade her to't, let her e'ne live
Till ſhe be thought ſo much a Ghoſt, that the ſtate
Command her take a houſe in a Church-yard,
And never walke but at midnight.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: What do they ſay Lelia?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Forſooth deviſing for your worſhips good.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Kind heart! me thinks you are not merry Sir.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Who, I? as joviall as a condemn'd man I.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Will you fit down and eat a little broth?

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: I ſhall be cawdled like a Haberdaſhers wife
That lies inn of her firſt child; but methinks
Upon a ſtricter view you look not well,
Your bloud abſents it ſelfe, are you not faint?

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: I, and her eyes ſhrinke, and retire into
Their melancholly cells; your breath ſmells ſomewhat
Of earth too, but 'tis nor much.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: By'rlady but take heed, my Grandam thus
Was taken ſpinning at her wheele, and dy'd
So quickly (as they ſay) as one would wiſh.

sp.speaker: Triſt.
sp.l: I've ſeene a Coarſe look better in a ſhrowd.
If you have any buſineſſe now with heaven
'Twere fit your prayers were ſhort, for I much feare
You'l not have breath enough to utter it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: 'Tis more than I feele; look I ſo ill Lelia?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: As you were wont forſooth, moſt ſtrange and uggly.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Come, leade me in: pray husband do not grieve,
Tis but a ſit that ever takes me once
In fifty yeares: but weepe hot, 'twill away.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Every teare ſhall be as big as a turnip
When I weepe; the good pox comfort you, Wench
Follow the game cloſe, ſtill breath death to her.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Warrant you ſir, I cannot do a better
Deed than put her in mind ſtill of her end.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Marry a widow, and be coffind up
VVith clouts and a skelliton? by this day,
I lay laſt night lock'd in ſurgeons box;
Compard unto her bed, a Pothecaries bing
Is a Venetian cowch, and Canopie.

sp.speaker: Alte.
sp.l: Thoſe that ſeek gold, muſt dig for it in mines.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: VVell my camp companions, what thinke you now
O'th court? I am ſent for thither to take charge
Of what is yet the moitie of a miracle.
But you are all content to thrive, to jet
And ſtrut like luſtfull Turkeys with your plumes ſpread.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: Tis not amiſſe; my good Lord Frivilo,
I kiſſe your ſoft hands; noble ſir keepe on
Your Cordovan, I ſweare your glove is a
Preferment, 'bove the merit of my lips.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: You cheriſh my ambition ſir—ſignieur

sp.speaker: Triſtan?
sp.l: your profeſs'd ſlave: I pray keepe on
Your way, I'ld rather build another wall
Than to diſhonor you by taking this.

sp.speaker: Triſt.
sp.l: Beleeve it ſir, both hands muſt be cut off
Ere I miſtake to place you neere the left.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: This practiſe will do well, follow apace,
I muſt with ſpeed to Caladine.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: 'Tis ſtrange, it ſeemes he knowes me not, and that
The falſly, kind Melora weares my name
He ſpeakes as if her life he tendred more
Than mine, 't is a miſtake I faine would cheriſh.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I did not thinke the ſtock of nature could,
In this her colder age, be rich enough
To ſtore the world with two ſuch beauties that
Together take their growth, and flouriſhing,
And this unto my inſtant judgement ſeemes
(If ſuch amazeing formes admit of difference)
The more exact, but that the blood & ſtile
Of Princeſs makes the other claime our reverence
As well as love, and for Alvaro's ſake, I wiſh
I could procure that ſhe might live.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: I have conſider'd what you told me ſir,
And though the Princeſſe through a fond exceſſe
Of love, would haſten a calamity
That all the world muſt grieve and wonder at,
Yet I could give her reaſon an excuſe,
For I my ſelfe to eaſe her ſufferance
Could willingly indure the ſame.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: It ripens more, and ſwifter than my hopes
Deſigne; you reach at an ambition Lady,
So great and good, my wonder interrupts
My language ſtill, I cannot prais't enough.
Can ſuch a vertuous courage dwell in your ſex?

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: If you uprightly love her and the Prince,
(Whoſe care ſhe is) ſtraight leade me to the Duke,
And try how reall my profeſſions are.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Forgive the office you invite me to,
Which by the hopes of my religion could
My life excuſe, I ſhould eſteem't too cheape
An offering; this, Lady, is the fatall way—

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Melora, now my fortune is above
Thy art, and I ſhall equall thee in love.
sp.stage: Enter Duke (with Letters) Vaſco, Alteſto, Frivolo, Triſtan, Attendants.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Againe in low petitionarie ſtile
He beggs me by theſe letters to releaſe
His daughter, and doth proffer ſummes ſo vaſte
To ranſome her, as would orecome the covetous:
But I have ſent him ſuch deniall, with
Diſdaine, as muſt diſtract and breake his heart.
Vaſco, yo've heard how ill I am obeyd
By theſe perſum'd ſmooth traitors of the Court,
And I have choſen you to ſhow a duty
Fitting the ſtricter diſcipline of warre,
To actuate all my wil with inſtant diligence.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: You muſt injoyne me ſir commands that are
Moſt horrid, and unnaturall, when I
Prove ſlow, or faint to execute.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: If theſe your officers and friends become
Diſloyall to your will, you may provide
The rack and tortures to inforce em too't.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: If their own appetites wil not perſwade.
There is ſmall hope from puniſhment.
Marke ſir, that whey-fac'd fellow in the red,
The Rack is his delight, and gives him as
Much eaſe, as when he's ſtretch'd with lazineſſe
And a coole mornings ſleepe.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Is't poſſible!

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: I've ſeene him ſuffer the Strapado thrice,
Hang in this politique poſture in the ayre,
As he were ſtudying to circumvent nature,
And no ſooner downe but calls for a wench.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: I know you have the skill to govern them.
Be ſure that Proſpero's houſe be diggd untill
The pinacles and the foundations meet.
Vnleſſe they deale by ſorcery and charmes,
I'le finde theſe buried lovers out, and my
Falſe ſonne the Prince, that covets darkenes more
Than bleſſed light, or my reſpect.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: I doe not like this buſineſſe ſhould concerne
The Prince; although the rack be ſomewhat out
Of ſeaſon with my old bones, for his ſake
I ſhall become a parcell traytor too.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I feard that Caladine delaying his
Returne ſo long, might fruſtrate all my glory;
And how Evandra's skill might worke with him
Was dangerous. I doe not ſee her here.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Pray heaven my Maſter do not check my forwardneſs
T'obey your will; he meant you ſhould keepe home.

sp.speaker: Melo.
sp.l: My preſence here will make his benefit;
I told thee ſo before; truſt my excuſe in thy behalfe.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: What Ladye's that?

sp.speaker: Melo.
sp.l: One that to pleaſure you with a revenge,
Preſent my ſelfe to execution, with
As liberall ioy, as to the marriage prieſt.
And when I name my ſelfe Evandra, you
Will know enough to ſatisfie your wrath.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Is the belov'd Bird flown from the darke cage?
Their magick was not ſtrong enough to hinder deſtinie,
And you will find ſmall am'rous pitty in
My frozen age. My guard ceaze on her ſtraight.
sp.stage: Enter a Guard, and bind her.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: Vaſco, this is Melora my priſoner?

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Peace Devill, peace, thou wilt deſtroy brave myſteries.
A noble girle; I conceive all; now would
My gratious widow be burnt to char-coale
Ere ſhe had braine, or nature for a plot
Like this; I could eat her, and her cloathes too,
By this hand, her very ſhooes were a rare meſſe.

sp.speaker: Melo.
sp.l: Yf you expect to find me here a lowly ſutor,
Tis but to haſten ſir your glad content
With a diſpatch upon my life, and that
The Prince may be • ton'd unto your love.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Her ſpirit ſeemes to ſtir my manhood more
Than it aſtoniſheth my ſence. I am
Reſolv'd to farther your deſires (brave dame)
With all the helpe of cruelty and haſte.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Death ſlave, what make you here? the Princeſſe too?
Why did you give her liberty?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: She told me ſir, it was with your conſent.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: She hath ore'reach'd my skill, I am undone.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Stay Caladine, another prize? come back
And render me that Ladies name.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: He knows it not; my name's Evandra ſir.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I feare I am depriv'd of my intent.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: We muſt to Delphos ſure t'untie theſe doubts
And wonders with an Oracle.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Do not beleeve that Lady ſir, ſhe hath
Beguil'd me of my name, and is ſo ſick
And fond with an improper love, ſhe would
Betray her ſelf unto a paine, ſhe knows
Not how to merit nor endure like me.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: O Sir, I find her language is moſt apt
And powerfull to perſwade, but let your faith
Conſider my affections too.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Why doſt thou let thy kindneſſe wrong we thus,
Undoing thy Religion with thy love?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: 'Tis you confer the Injury, that will
Not ſuffer me to dye in peace.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Rare wenches both; all this is for the Prince.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Though ſmall inquiry would diſcover ſoone
Who juſtifies the truth, yet I will end
The difference ſo as ſhall afford you equall joy,
And not endanger a miſtake in me;
Convey them to the Fort, they ſhall both die.
sp.stage: The Guard laies hold on them.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Hath this Duke buried all his goodneſſe in's
Reverge! ſure he is libd, he hath certainely
No maſculine buſineſſe about him.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Lead them away.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ile follow too, and mourne the obſequy
Ere ceremonious death make it compleat.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Forgive this emulation (Madam) you
Shall know a cauſe that will invite you to't.

sp.speaker: Evand.
sp.l: Poore Melora! I pitty not my ſelf but thee
sp.stage: Exeunt Cal. Evand. Mel. and Guard.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Now let my Son, and's Minion Proſpero
(Rebellious as himſelf) reſign toth' Fiends
Their dark and hidden tenements again,
Come forth free and ſecure, for ſince they valued death
As a delight they ſhall not ſuffer it;
Go ſtraite proclame their next appearance ſafe,
For it wil pleaſure me they ſhould ſtand by
To ſee, and not be able to reſiſt, the juſtice of revenge.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Sure revenge is a ſtrange kind of Lechery;
How it hath alterd him!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Vaſco, now the inchanted houſe may ſtand;
But be you here to morrow with ſome ſtrength
To guard their execution from impediments
Of rage, or pitty; they ſhall ſuffer early.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: I thank your grace for any employment.
Alteſto, art thou a rogue?

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: A little (Sir) infected with your company.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Art thou ſo very a rogue, if I command.
Thee from the Duke, to cut off theſe Ladies heads,
Thou'lt whet the Axe thy ſelf, and doit with the
Dexterity of a Flemming?

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: I will ſee thy head in a leatherne caſe firſt,
Kickt in a footbal match from gole to gole.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Why I thank thee; what ſay you Frivolo,
Wenches and Surgeons have coſt you deare,
Have you remorſe enough to do't?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: I've a mind rather to rebell, break ſhops
Open, and make choice of my ſilks, without
Taking notice (ſir) of the Mercers book.

sp.speaker: Triſt
sp.l: Such wholſome buſineſſe would more take me too
Than cutting off poore Ladies heads, unleſs
Your faire widow (Vaſco) come in my reach,
I could behead her for her left eare ring,
Though it be but an Agat ſet in Copper.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Come let's to bed; the Sun to morrow will
Riſe black, or I ſhall think him a dull inſenſible
Planet, and deſerves no more adoration than a farthing candle.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Sir, you have heard how ſhe betraid me to
A Vow, and with what cruell menacings
My Siſter and her ſelf petitiond heaven
T'aſſiſt their curſes in a puniſhment
Upon my after-life, if I were perjur'd by
A breach of what my promiſe did aſſure.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: It was a vow no leſſe unkind than rare,
T'impriſon us that had no cauſe nor will
To do a noble ſtranger injury;
But I have learnt a tame Philoſophy,
Perſwades me to forgive all but my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: How comes the date of your ſtrict vow expir'd,
And that you now afford us liberty?
Which if my memory be juſt, you ſaid
She did enjoyne you ſhould not be, ere ſhe
Was gone to ſuffer death.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Sir, ſhe is gone, my Siſter too; one that
Attends by your command theſe hidden walks
In breathleſſe haſte juſt now diſtill'd the poiſonous news
Through my ſick eare.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Gone? and to dye? adorn'd
(Me thinks) like to an ancient ſacrifice
With flowers, which are not ſure the iſſue of
The ſpring, but of her beauty, and her breath.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Would I had patience to endure calamities
Like this! but I'm forbid by my galld heart;
Why did you keep us limited and lockt
I'th Cave when we had power to hinder her
Departure, and her death? 'twas a bold crime.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Sir, I have hope I gaind your pardon when
I mention'd the misfortune of my vow.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I underſtand not ſuch injurious vows:
Thou lov'dſt her Leonel, and through the pride
Of envy couldſt not yeeld, ſince thy own hopes
Grew faint, that mine ſhould ere be proſperous;
Therefore with cunning willingneſſe endur'd
Her deſp'rate fally to the Duke.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: That I did love her ſir is a moſt true
And fitting glory to proclame; but that
I'm guilty of ſo baſe a ſlander as
Your raſhneſs hath devis'd provokes me to
A rage that may prove dangerous: reclame
Your thoughts, and teach them more civility.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: The Prince grows ſolemne with his griefe, leſt we
Diſturbe him let's retire aſide, and Ile
Whiſper ſuch reaſons to thee as ſhall want
No courage to be truths, though they inflame.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Fountaines that ever weep have in their teares
Some benefit, they coole the parched earth,
And cheriſh a perpetuall growth; the ſad
Arabian tree that ſtill in Baulmy drops
Diſſolves her life, doth yield for others help
A medicine in thoſe teares: but triviall man
Though he hath ſence to mourne, may weep and melt
His injur'd eyes to viewleſſe aire, yet all
Th' expence affords is vainely to diſcerne
His mourning gives his ſorrows life, and length,
But not the guiltleſſe cauſe a remedy.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: My Lord, I ſtayd upon the garden Mount,
And in the heate of my impatience was
So kind, much to lament your tardineſſe;
But now I muſt have leave to think one that
Delights to heape up wrongs, hath fury more
To dare than do.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Were this a Temple, and the Prince
Imploy'd i'th rev'rend buſineſſe of a Prieſt,
I could not ſuffer ſuch a boaſt from one
That I have us'd with ſo much clemency
In fight—defend thy life, or it is mine.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Are you ſo maſterly—again—I find
No lightning in your eyes, nor in your ſword.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: You have the skill, but I'le diſtemper it—

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Hold, hold, eager and ſilly miniſters
Of wrath, is this a time to bleed, when ere
The morning ſun uncloud his penſive face,
There will bee ſtreames of blood let out enough
To make him drinke till he be ſick with ſacrifice?
Give me thy ſword. How Proſpero? are my
Commands grown weariſome and cold—

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: There ſir—I'm ſtill rebuk'd like to a boy.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: How long ſhall I direct thy temper to
A gentle and a ſoft demeane ere thou
Grow wiſe, and milde Enough to governe it?
Let me intreat you ſir, to ſheath your weapon too.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Sir, you are worthy to command; and know
I weare it for my guard, not inſolence.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: I am appointed all my actions ſtill,
As my ſtupiditie made me not fit
To know, but ſuffer injuries.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Why doſt thou frowne? the ſullen wrinckles on
A lyons brow carry a grace, 'cauſe they
Become a beaſt, but he that can diſcerne
The nobleneſs of valor ſhould be ſmooth
As Virgins in their bridall ornaments.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Sir, I am taught; how ere my ſences are
Not ſo miſtaken and ſo weake, but that
They know him falſe; he lov'd Evandra.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Is that a crime? thou told'ſt me in the cave
Thou lov'dſt her too.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: I nere durſt tell you ſo,
Till you diſcern'd my paſſions, and inforc'd
A true diſcoverie of their hidden cauſe.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: But I eſteem'd it for a vertue knowne,
And it indeerd thee more to my reſpect.
Pray tell me ſir, did you love Evandra?
And with a heart ſincere as ſhe deſerv'd?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Sir, the confeſſion may be honour, but
No ſhame I did, and with a ſervencie
Vpright as my Religion could produce.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: O what a prompt and warme delight I feele
When others reaſon are inclin'd unto
My choyce? 'tis ſtrange the ſenceleſſe world ſhould ſo
Miſtake the privilege of love, the beſt
Of objects! heaven affects plurallitie
Of worſhipers, t'adore and ſerve, whilſt we
In that chiefe hope are glad of Rivalſhip;
And why ſhould Ladies then that imitate
The upper beauty moſt to mortall view,
Be barr'd a numerous adreſſe? or we
Envie each others lawfull, though ambitious aime?
Come, joyne your hands, and ſeale a friendſhip here,
Good as inviolate, laſting as truth.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You give my wiſhes ſir, a full content.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: I want the skill to promiſe ſir, but Ile
Performe all your deſires with noble ſaith.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: And now let me imbrace you both, for we
Are lovers all, though when the morne muſt riſe
To ſee and bluſh at th'actions of the world,
Like ſad diſtreſſed Turtles we ſhall want
Our mate, then we may ſit and mourne beneath
The willow that ore'ſhaddowes every brook,
There weepe, till we are vaniſht quite in teares
T'increaſe the ſtreame, whoſe ſenceleſs murmurings
Will be excus'd hereafter in our cauſe.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: O that my heart would be the officer
Of death unto it ſelfe, and breake without
My irreligious helpe; my life is tir'd.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And I have thoughts ſo wild, ſo much unſafe,
They would be ſinne in utterance, as in act.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Give me your hands; with a ſlow fun'rall pace
Weel move, to ſee this diſmall Tragedie.
Let's beare it bravely, like ſuch lovers as
Have reaſon can perſwade their courage to
Attempt things bold and fit; whil'ſt there was hope,
We cheriſh'd it with proffer of our lives,
But now the ſtrength of Armies cannot free
Her from my fathers wrath; nay, hand in hand—
To ſhew this truth in loves Philoſophy,
That as one object equally allures
Th'ambition of our hope, ſo we not interchange
Malignant thoughts; but ſev'rall lovers, like
Strange Rivers that to the ſame Ocean trace,
Do when their torrents meet, curle and embrace.

div.head: Act. 5. Scaena. 1.
div.stage: Enten 2. Embaſſadours with letters, Caladine, Vaſco, Alteſto, Frivolo.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Your Letters merit to have power on my
Reſpect and diligence; I ſhall afford
You both; but when I bring you to the Duke
'Tis to be fear'd you'l find the privilege
Of all my favor there is loſt.

sp.speaker: 1 Emb.
sp.l: Acceſſe and audience Sir is all our hopes
Preſume to get, the times befriend us not.

sp.speaker: 2 Emb.
sp.l: We had ſwift notice of theſe Ladies danger;
And Sir, how ere it prove, your wiſhes muſt
Oblige us to a laſting gratitude.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: What are theſe ſtrangers Vaſco, that envy
Our ſleep, and wake us before day?

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Embaſſadors from Millaine, whoſe hopes want
Some cordiall water, for they'r very ſick.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Vaſco, it is the Dukes command that you
Aſſemble ſtraight ſome ſtrength from the caſt Regiments
To guard the Pallace yard.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: What need it Sir? to my knowledge the two Ladits have no
Other weapons than Bodkins, and their nailes
Cloſſe par'd; beſides, a thread of Eglantine,
Or a ſmall wood bine ſtalke, will ſetter them
As faſt as Cables of a Galley-groſſe.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I but deliver what I had in charge.
My Lords Embaſſadors this is your way.

sp.speaker: 1 Emb.
sp.l: Theſe preparations are ſevere; I doubt
His mind will not be eaſily reclaim'd.

sp.speaker: 2 Emb.
sp.l: You ſee the gen'rous people like it not.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Alteſto, go and muſter up from all
The Lanes and Alleys in the Town a troop
Of fine fleet rogues, ſuch as will turne their backs
To a bullet and outrun it, yet love
Commotion too, I would have ſuch Alteſto,

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Let me furniſh you; hell ſhall not yeeld a Regiment
Of Fiends that will be more inviſible
At the approach of Juſtice or Religion.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: O for a tiny ſhort truſs'd Bakes that
I knew; A Carman too, that dy'd ſome three
Months ſince with eating meazled porke; they would
Have march'd to ſuch a war with cowleſtaffe and
Batoone like Hercules.
sp.stage: Enter Triſtan (leading the Widow) and Lelia.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: How now? whither move you ſo faſt, like a
Fleet ſnaile over a cabidge leaf, ſo early too?
She ſleeps leſſe than carriers, traytors, or Madmen.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: She requeſts me to be the ſtaffe of her age.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: But whither I pray?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Why ſir, to ſee the ſhew.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: The ſhew! the motion of Queene Guinivers death
Acted by puppets would pleaſe you as well;
The Jade too is as full of remorſe as
A Beare that wants his ſupper.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I would have a ſafe place, where I may ſtand
And weep without having my handkerchiefe
Stolne away.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: It is of pure Cambrick forſooth,
And made of her Grandmothers wedding Apron.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Yes truly, and wrought when I was a maid.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: That's an antiquity beyond all record.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Sirra Triſtan, be you ſure you avoid
No throng; a croud well ſhuffled, and cloſe pack'd,
May do now a ſpeciall courteſie;
Let her be ſqueez'd, for ſhe's as rotten as
A hollow tree that ſtands without a root.

sp.speaker: Triſt.
sp.l: My ſhoulder ſhall help too at a dead lift.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: A Scaffold that were weakly built would ſerve.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: VVe muſt make haſte; farewell Lambe.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Lambe, which my own tranſlation renders calfe.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: 'Twill be long ere thou grow up to a bull:
For few will venter to help thee to hornes.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: VVell Gentlemen pitty my caſe, I have
Endur'd another night would tire a Perdu,
More than a wet furrow and a great froſt.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: VVill ſhe not dye?

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: I have perſwaded her, but ſtill in vaine;
And all the help the Laws afford us poore
Miſtaken men, that marry gold inſtead
Of fleſh, is a divorſe, it muſt be thought
On ſuddenly; Alteſto, haſte to your charge.

sp.speaker: Alteſt.
sp.l: Good morrow Cavaliers.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: 'Twill be an houre yet before that greeting
Be in ſeaſon; pray heaven Triſtan remember the crowd.
sp.stage: Enter Alvaro, Proſpero, Leonel. and Boy (to ſing.)

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: This glorious hazzard in thy ſiſter (Leonel)
Doth equally perplex my ſufferance
With what the faire Evandra muſt endure.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You now have heard the chearefull Art ſhe us'd
To be the firſt that ſhould confirme her love
With proſtitution of her virgin life.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: But why for me? how poore they make me now,
That have betra'yd me to a debt the wealth
Of Saints (that are in kindneſſe ever rich)
Is not of able value to diſcharge;
I love them both with equall flame, and I
Diſtinguiſh neithers beauty when compar'd;
'Tis vertue and remorce give Ladies eminence
In the ſevere diſcretion of my heart.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I want the wiſdome how to love; but I
Am ſure I find I love, and 'tis too much

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Come ſing; would muſick had the power to give
A life, as it hath had to move things dead.

lg.l: O draw your Curtaines and appeare, Ere long, like ſparkes that upward flie,
We can but vainly ſay you were, So ſoon you'l vaniſh from the eye.
And in what Star we both ſhall find (For ſure you can't divided be)
Is not to Lovers Art aſſign'd, 'Twill puzzle wiſe Aſtrology.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Who is it that aſſumes the office of
The dying Swan? all Muſick now (me thinks)
Is obſequy, and he that fings ſhould ſing his death.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: The gentle and moſt valiant Prince, bold Proſpero.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: And there behold the faithfull Leonell.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: O pardon me that I have kept my vow.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Brave youth! I prize thy truth great as thy love;
We now are mark'd here, and inclos'd for death,
So you have all a bleſſed liberty.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: A liberty? we are more bound than ſlaves unto
Th' unwieldy oare; like harneſs'd cattell in
A Teeme, we draw a load of ſorrow after us
That tires our ſtrength.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: There was no way but this
To keep you ſtill among the living, who
Before endeavour'd nobly to procure
Our freedome with your deaths; do not repine
At deſtiny, all remedy is paſt.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: A fatall truth; for we but now dejected on our knees
Did wooe my Fathers mercy, and in vaine.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Then ſtrive not by untimely rage to help
And further our impoſſible releaſe
With certaine hazzard of your ſelves; our laſt
Sute is, we may begin our willing death
As quietly as undiſturbed ſleep.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: The silly crime of envy which unlearn'd
And haughty Lovers uſe, I ſhall prevent;
You'l want the object now, that makes you interchange
The vext remembrance of each others claime.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Were you to live we could not ſhare that guilt;
Though number make us three, wiſe love hath given
Us all one peacefull heart.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: O Melora! were it but timely now
To wiſh continuance of mortality,
Like them, we ſhould not differ though the ſame
One virtue were our mutuall hope and choice;
But you ſhould chide her ſir, for ſhe hath lov'd
Your happineſſe too much, vainely to loſe
Her life when mine would ſatisfie.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Why Melora didſt thou undo my ſoule
VVith ſo ſtrange courteſie? but why did you
Evandra? ſtay, o ſtay, leave us not yet.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: The Guard are entred here, and now the laſt
And ſhorteſt of our houres is come; farewell
Brave Prince; brave Leonell farewell; farewell brave Proſpero.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: The gentle valiant Prince
Farewell; and valiant Leonell farewell;
Farewell the hardy Proſpero Ex. from above.
sp.stage: Leon. and Pro. draw their ſwords.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Nay, ſtir not Gentlemen, it is in vaine,
They are beyond all humane help; would you
Scale heaven, and coole the ſawcy Sun with your
Fraile breath when he doth ſcorch you with his beames?
For ſuch is now the enterpriſe that ſtrives
To reſcue them from this high Fort.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Would I were in a Cannon charg'd, then ſtraight
Shot out to batter it, and be no more.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Would all the ſtones might be ordain'd my food
Till I could eat their paſſage out.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Theſe angry exaltations ſhew but poore.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Sir, whither ſhall we go?

sp.speaker: Alva
sp.l: To ſee them dye; but not like vaine and colerick boyes, to ſhew
A fury that can hazzard none but our
Diſdained ſwords; yet ſtill my worthy friends
There is an undertaking left, and ſuch
As valiant lovers may performe; why ſhould
The baſe and durty Guard be honour'd with
Our oppoſition or our bloud? have we
Not griefe enough to dye without their help?
Let us with fix'd and watry eyes behold
Theſe Ladies ſuffer, but with ſilence ſtill,
Calmely like pinion'd doves, and when we ſee
The fatall ſtroak is given, ſwell up our ſad
And injur'd hearts untill they break.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I do not find my ſelf unapt for this.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: My breaſt containes an angry lump that is
Too ſtubborne for a quiet bravery;
He that ſhall ſtrike Evandras life ſhall feele
Me till he ſink low as the hollowneſſe where Devills dwell.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: This way; let us avoid the gazing multitude.
sp.stage: Enter Duke, Caladine, Vaſco, 2 Embaſſadors, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Have you unto your Officers given charge
To guard the paſſage from the Fort unto
The Pallace yard with bold well-govern'd men?

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: All is directed Sir as you command;
But for their government, if it be to be had
In priſons, galleys, or ſtews, you may
Truſt them with a mutiny.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: His reſolution's fi'xd, and there remaines
No comfortable ſigne to flatter hope.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: My Lords Embaſſadors ſit down; and though
You now behold a Prince that rather loves
To be thought cruell than to break his vow,
Do not beleeve to be ſeverely juſt
Is tyranny; you ſhall have faire admittance,
Yet your requeſt unkindly ought to be
Deny'd; and though your Maſter (when the chance
Of war rendred my brother in his power)
Stole in the dark his noble life, and durſt
Not give the wrathfull act a gen'rall view;
I'm not aſham'd to publiſh my revenge,
It ſhall be openly perform'd, to ſhew
I not ſuſpect mens cenſure or diſlike.

sp.speaker: 1 Emb.
sp.l: Sir, he that miniſters revenge may hurt
And damage others, but can bring no good
Or reall profit to himſelfe.

sp.speaker: 2 Emb.
sp.l: And with your Highneſſe leave, we think it were
More wiſe to mulct our Maſters treaſure, which
Shall be exhauſted freely to your own
Proportion and content, ſo you will take
His Daughter and her lov'd companion from
The danger of this day.
sp.stage: Enter Evandra, Melora, Guard, at one doore: Alvaro, Proſpero, Leonell, at the other.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I will not ſell my brothers bloud;
The priſoners approach; make roome; ere long
They ſhall enjoy the liberty of ſoules;
Vaſco, lend me thine eare.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: How beautifull is ſorrow when it dwells
Within theſe Ladies eyes? ſo comely, that it makes
Felicity in others ſeeme deform'd.
I wiſh my patience may be ſtrong enough.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I now begin to doubt I am not fit
To ſee their hazard and indur't.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Nor I; my loyalty already ſtird
Beyond the temp'rate ſuff'rance of a man.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Thou ſeeſt the Prince weares trouble in his locks;
Though any oppoſition he can make
Be but impertinent and weak, yet charge
Thy Officers, if he endeavor to
Diſturbe my will, impriſon him i'th Fort.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: I ſhall obſerve him Sir; I do not like
This employment; the Prince will find no
Enemies in all my tribe.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: If you have any words from Millaine th • t
Imports their knowledge, ere they dye, be briefe
My Lords Embaſſadors; I give you leave
To whiſper your affaire, or if you pleaſe,
To make it publique to the world.

sp.speaker: 1 Emb.
sp.l: Your cruell reſolutions ſir, have ſo
Confin'd our liberality, that all
We ſhall deliver to Evandra now
Is but her Fathers and her Countries teares,
And thoſe we can by deputation pay
To the indang'ring of our eyes.

sp.speaker: 2 Emb.
sp.l: And to Melora, that in kindneſſe thus
Hath ſhar'd her deſtiny, we do confer
The worlds eternall wonder and applauſe.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: It will deprive me of ſome joy in death, to think
My Father needs muſt ſuffer by a vaine
Unprofitable griefe, and 'tis the laſt
Requeſt I make, that he would wiſely now
Forget my obſequies and name.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: And my deſires make ſute, that thoſe who ſhall
Hereafter write the buſineſſe of this day
May not beleeve I ſuffer for the hope
Of glorious Fame, but for a ſecret in my hidden love.

sp.speaker: 1 Emb.
sp.l: Queſtion your juſtice Sir, muſt they both dye?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Both; and I think my payment is but ſhort,
When I conſider well the meaſure of
My brothers worth, with their unvalu'd Sex,
And wiſh ſome man that boaſts your maſters bloud
Were ſingly here to undergoe their fate,
It would more pleaſure my revenge, but ſince
There is no hope in that deſire, away, lead them to death.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Stay Sir, reprieve them but one minutes ſpace
Untill you heare a ſtranger ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: What meanes this noble youth?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Be ſudden in thy ſpeech, for my revenge brooks no delay.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: If I produce a man ally'd unto this Family you ſo abhor,
Great as your ſelfe in title and deſcent,
Will you with ſolemne vow confirme their liberty,
And take his life to ſatisfie your wrath?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: By th' honour of a Princes faith I wil;
And ſuch a miracle would raviſh me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I dare beleeve your vow, you were ſo juſt
Though cruell in your laſt, and know my joyes
Muſt take the privilege to boaſt you now
Have loſt the power to make them dye.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: It ſhall be wonderfull if that prove true.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I am not Leonell the Millaine Knight,
But Leonell the Duke of Parmas Son,
Heire to his fortune and his fame.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: O Melora! thy brother will reveale
Himſelfe and quite undoe our glorious ſtrife.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: By this you find I am to Millaine neer
Ally'd; but more to tempt your fury on
My life, know 'twas my valiant Father took
Your brother priſoner, and preſented him
Where he receiv'd his death; my Father that
So oft hath humbled you in war, and made
His victories triumph almoſt upon
The ruines of your State.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: So young, and fill'd with thoughts ſo excellent,
That they ſurpriſe my wonder more than love!
Well mayeſt thou worſhip, Proſpero, but darſt not envy him.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: B'ing your Diſciple Sir,
I'm better taught; but 'tis no crime to wiſh
Fortune had made me Heire of Parma and
Not him, then I had dy'd for them.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: This is ſome comfort yet; I'm for the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: But 'thath not given our ſorrows a full cure.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Sir you are boldeſt with your ſelfe; but you
Shall ſee I need no provocation to
Obſerve my vow; unbind the Ladies there,
And beare him ſtraight to death.

sp.speaker: 1 Emb.
sp.l: Stay Sir, he muſt not dye.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: How? age and griefe makes thee a foole, and mad.

sp.speaker: 1 Em.
sp.l: He muſt not Sir, if your revenge be wiſe,
And fix your anger where 'tis moſt deſerv'd;
Behold Millaine himſelfe your Enemy;
Live princely youth, and let my yeares (which time
Would ſoone determine) be the ranſome of
My chiefeſt bloud; Evandra do not weep.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: O Sir, there was leſſe uſe of me; why would
You with this danger on your ſelfe deſtroy
That noble fame I vertuouſly purſu'd?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Our hope of endleſſe glory now is loſt.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Sure heaven intends more bleſſings to this day.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I have atchiev'd my wiſhes in full height;
This was a juſtice ſir, more than I could
Expect from my own Stars; free Leonell
And let him ſuffer the prepared ſtroake.

sp.speaker: 2 Emb.
sp.l: Firſt heare me ſpeak, and fir how ever you'l
Interpret the diſcretion of my words
I am reſolv'd he ſhall not dye, nor none
Of theſe, though all in your command and power.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Say'ſt thou ſo old Shaver? make but that good,
The maids of Savoy ſhall everlaſtingly
Pay thee tribute in dainty gloves and Noſegays
To ſtick in thy girdle.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: This were a myſtery would pleaſe indeed.

sp.speaker: 2 Emb.
sp.l: Look on me well: I am your brother Sir;
And though ten years I have been hidden from
Your ſight, this noble Duke hath us'd me ſo,
I cannot call it baniſhment, but the
Retir'd and quiet happineſſe of life.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: How wiſely have the heavens contriv'd this joy!

sp.speaker: 1 Emb.
sp.l: And though his fortune in the war, which made
Your Armies ever flouriſh with ſucceſſe,
Taught me prevent my Countries ruine by
Detaining him from your employment there,
Yet he enjoy'd all the delights that ſolitude
Affords: and when he choſe his happineſſe
In Books and deep Diſcourſes of the learn'd,
I ſearch'd the moſt remote and knowing world
For men to furniſh his deſires.

sp.speaker: 2 Emb.
sp.l: It is acknowledg'd ſir, and with a bounteous thanks.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: How welcome are theſe miracles? let me
Embrace thee as the greateſt joy that ſince
My birth I have receiv'd. O my lov'd brother,
Thou ſee'ſt though abſent I've been faithfull to
Thy vertues, and thy memorie.

sp.speaker: 2. Emb.
sp.l: But ſir, too ſtrict a maſter of your vow;
Yet tis a fault my gratitude ſhould more
Admire with thankfulneſſe, than chide.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: This happy day deſerves a place ſupreme
And eminent i'th Kallander.

sp.speaker: 2. Emb.
sp.l: Firſt I will give into your courteous armes
The Duke of Millaine ſir, good & renoun'd;
And now the bold and princely Leonell;
Then Alvaro my honourd nephew that
Deſerves the beſt of humane praiſe and love.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Dread ſir, that every one may ſhare the joy
And bleſſings of this precious houre, let me
Reſtore poore Proſpero into your breaſt.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: He ſhall bee cheriſh'd and his faults forgiven.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: I ſhall deſerve it ſir in future deeds
Of honour, and of loyall faith; how I
Am rap'd to ſee thoſe wonders ſtrangely thrive?

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: What thinke you of the ſtarrs now Caladine?
Doe theſe ſmall twinkling Gentlewomen
Looke to their buſineſs well? have they a care of us?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: It is beyond our merit or our hope.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Ile buy me an optick, ſtudy Aſtrologie,
And viſit e'm ev'ry faire night ore my houſe leds.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: The chiefeſt happineſs of virtue is
Th'increaſe, which to procure, with Hymens help
Wee'l knit, and intermingle lovers hearts.
Come my Alvaro, Ile beſtow thee ſtraight.

sp.speaker: Melo.
sp.l: A little patience ſir, and heare me ſpeake
Before you give what lawfully is mine.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Indeed thou doſt deſerve him by thy love.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: In love Evandras intereſt juſtly
Doth equall mine, but I appeale unto
His vow, which ſure her goodneſſe will aſſiſt.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: And my religion ſhall perſwade me keepe;
But where (Melora) was it made?

sp.speaker: Melo.
sp.l: Within my fathers court, when five yeares ſince
(Diſguis'd you ſtole to ſee a triumph there)
You promis'd if our houſes enmity
VVere ever reconcil'd, the church ſhould joyne our hands.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Sir, VVhat my ſiſter ſpeakes I'm witneſſe to,
And hope this day ſhall end our parents ſtrife
In a kinde peace.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: VVhich thus I doe confirme;
Take him Melora, with him all the joyes
Thy virtues or our prayers can procure.

sp.speaker: Alva.
sp.l: Didſt thou for this with kind Evandra ſtrive
VVho ſhould encounter danger firſt? although
Thy beauty's chang'd, it is not loſt; I now
Remember thee, and my vowes prophecie.

sp.speaker: 1. Emb.
sp.l: Now my beſt Evandra give me thy hand;
And heare receive it valiant Leonell;
That I may ratifie the faith I gave,
If ere this war expir'd ſhe ſhould be thine.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Then hee may challenge preſent intereſt,
For we may meet to heare voyces and lutes,
But never more the angry Drum.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: Alvaro's virtues ſir, and yours, have both
An equall claim; perſons I nere admir'd
So much to make a difference in my choyce;
Therefore my fathers promiſe, and my love
Have made me yours.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: I am orecharg'd with my felicitie.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: To Evandra, gladneſs be ſtil renew'd,
VVho ſince I ſee ſo worthily beſtow'd,
My love is quieted in everlaſting reſt.

sp.speaker: Evan.
sp.l: And mine by your exact, and perfect choyce.

sp.speaker: Proſ.
sp.l: Theſe glad archievements are ſo well deſerv'd,
I not maligne your loyes; Ile to the warr
And fight to win you a perpetuall peace.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: I'm bold to crave acquaintance with your grace,
And to begin it with a ſute.

sp.speaker: 1 Emb.
sp.l: It ſhall be granted Sir.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: I have married your Graces Countrywoman,
And was a little (ſir) miſtaken in her age,
Would you'ld procure us a divorce.

sp.speaker: 1 Emb.
sp.l: If you can make't appeare ſhe is too old.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: She writes a hundred and ten (Sir) next graſſe.

sp.speaker: 1 Emb.
sp.l: 'Tis a faire age; well Sir, you ſhal have a divorce,
And what the profits of her dowry would
Have been, I will my ſelfe beſtow on you.

sp.speaker: Vaſ.
sp.l: Such another good day makes us all mad.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Come, to the Temple, and let's joyne thoſe hearts.
That with ſuch pious courage have endur'd
The tryall of a noble conſtant faith,
Whom tortures nor the frowns of death could move.
This happy day wee'l conſecrate to love.

l.hi: But that the Tyran cuſtome bears ſuch ſway,
We would preſent no Prologue to our Play,
Since we have learn'd in Prologues all the ſcope
Is with weak words to ſtrengthen weaker hope,
When with ſad ſolemn phraſe we court each eare
Not to obſerve, but pardon what you heare:
Or if there were but one ſo ſtrangely wiſe
Whoſe judgement ſtrives to pleaſe, and truſt his
Him at an eaſie charge we could provoke (eyes,
To a kind doome with this grave long old cloak.
Now for the over-ſubtle few, who raiſe
Themſelves a triviall fame by a diſpraiſe,
Our bold opinion is, they may deſcry
Some eaſie wit, but much more cruelty.
Troth Gentlemen you muſt vouchſafe a while
T' excuſe my mirth, I cannot chuſe but ſmile,
And 'tis to think, how like a ſubtle ſpy
Our Poet waits below to heare his deſtiny;
Juſt in the Entry as you paſſe, the place
Where firſt you mention your diſlike or grace:
Pray whiſper ſoftly that he may not heare,
Or elſe ſuch words as ſhall not blaſt his eare.
